141942: Heartlash Cinder.author: Treima
141942: Heartlash Cinder.text_parsed: Mediocre. If it comes out too soon it won't be powerful enough to make a difference, and it's only good for one shot regardless of whether or not your opponent has creatures. The dealbreaker is the lack of trample. It takes what could be a pretty good card for cheap mid-game damage and makes it a really narrow card that you can't depend on to take out anything bigger than Llanowar Elves.

142010: Inundate.author: Zulp
142010: Inundate.text_parsed: This card versus Wash Out is a pretty subjective thing, as far as I can see. This is more expensive, but will probably hit a lot more creatures, especially in multiplayer. Wash Out is narrower, but more useful in a duel, cheaper, and hits all permanents instead of just creatures. I think Inundate has better flavor. In addition, I don't know how much the "all permanents" clause really makes a difference in Wash Out's case. It cares about color, which mean it's most likely not going to get rid of a problem artifact or land, and when you return that pesky enchantment to its owner's hand, it's just going to come back. I'd say they're about even.

146006: Archon of Justice.author: Zulp
146006: Archon of Justice.text_parsed: Card advantage, people. If it dies in combat, chances are that its 4/4 body took whatever it was blocking or whatever was blocking it with it. Once that's out of the way, you get a free exile, which unlike O-ring can target a land, which can be extremely useful when you're staring down something like Library of Alexandria or Eye of Ugin. I put my opponents into hate mode every time I play this because they don't know what to do about it. It's a 4/4 flyer, so it will end the game relatively quickly if left alone. But if you kill it, chances are you're going to lose a crucial piece of tech or your own finisher. Great card, and amazing art, by the way. 4.5/5.

146010: Doomgape.author: majinara
146010: Doomgape.text_parsed:
It should be definately played with lightning greaves.

About the guy asking if you can use coffin queen with this guy to gain 10 life each turn: nope. Before this guys ability triggers at the upkeep, you have to choose if you want to untap the queen or not. If you untap it, the doomgape gets removed. And if you keep it tapped, you need to wait another turn to have the queen untapped and ready. So you could sac it once every two turns. But then I'd rather do something better with the queen. :)

146010: Doomgape.author: Qazior
146010: Doomgape.text_parsed:
About the Coffin Queen, it can be used every turn with this to gain 10 life (unless someone kills either).

The queen's ability says: "When Coffin Queen becomes untapped or you lose control of Coffin Queen, exile that creature." If you untap queen, the ability triggers. However, this is from MtG community Main rules FAQ:
Q: What happens when a triggered ability triggers during the Untap Step?
A: When a triggered ability triggers, it waits until the next time a player would receive priority to go on the stack. In this case, that means that the triggered ability wouldn't go on the stack until the upkeep step.

So the ability waits until upkeep and because you control both abilities (queen's and doomgape's) you can order them any way to stack. First queen's then gape's, gape's resolves first; you sac it, queen's resolves; doomgape is already gone so you don't have to exile it.

But to the card itself: 10/10 trample for 7 mana ain't bad and it's eating doesn't usually matter that much because it gives you life. 4.5/5

146010: Doomgape.author: Gaussgoat

Awesome creature... Total beast with trample who gains life and isn't too expensive. Yowza.

With Black/Green, it is entirely possible that this behemoth will hit the table as early as turn 4, and there are plenty of little guys to feast upon while he goes to work. The usual mana accelerators will help you... llanowar elves, dark ritual, Sacrifice, etc.

I'm wearing out his name, but this is yet another incredible card that works with Creakwood Liege. I mean, you're boosting Doomgape to a 12/12 AND providing a 3 point lifegain every turn. Yhatzee.

4.5/5

146010: Doomgape.author: Stray_Dog
146010: Doomgape.text_parsed:
First reaction: too few drawbacks to this creature for what you get. So what if you need to sacrifice a creature each turn? Unless it gets destroyed (which is harder than normal due to its high toughness and blackness) it will probably win the game for you in a turn or two, and if it does get destroyed you can sac it for ten life. Gaining life for the sacrifice is like a slap in the face for the player who doesn't use this card. I'm not saying the card is too good, because I honestly don't know, but its percieved power seems to be too much, at least for me. Too 'safe' really is what I would say.

Cards like this annoy me, because there is no reason NOT to play them. Think about it: if you were a casual deck-builder playing a green/black deck, why wouldn't you play this card? I think that it is important for cards not to be auto-include because if every card were like that then it would be almost impossible to choose what cards to put into a deck. Sure, sure, you could say that "card X deals with Doomgape easy" but the average casual player isn't going to know that, and especially not just from looking at the card. You could say that the sac effect would deter casual players, but that effect also comes with life gain, which casual players love.

Anyway I am sure there is a good rebuttal to what I am saying, and I would like to know what that is so I can better assess this card's fun value. At the moment it just irritates me (maybe that is the point of it? :P)

I think Xathrid Demon does it better. Does that card please Timmy? Doomgape's 10/10 looks alot bigger than 7/7 though.

146010: Doomgape.author: Salient
146010: Doomgape.text_parsed:
Dear Wizards of the Coast,

I would like more cards with "Doom" in the title, please. I would consider it a personal favor if any of those cards are also ridiculously oversized underprotected the-whole-table-laughs-when-it-hits-play mega-monsters with highly evocative art and enjoyable flavor text, but, really, that's much too much to ask, and to be honest I'm plenty satisfied with fun mediocre-even-in-casual-play junk like Doom Cannon. (And I think it'll be d*mn hard to top the name Doomgape.)

However, I have a small quibble. Next time you all decide to charge ahead and be bold and print a card this cool, could you please give it the Legendary supertype, so that I can play it as my commander in EDH?

Many thanks! 5+/5.

P.S. It's really not too late to bring back doom counters. Just saying.

P.P.S. Doomgape + Enduring Renewal may not be the most efficient combo in Magic, but it's one of the most beautiful and naturalistic. (Contrast with Smokestack + Crucible of Worlds, which is depressingly industrial.)

I would consider it a personal favor if any of those cards are also ridiculously oversized underprotected the-whole-table-laughs-when-it-hits-play mega-monsters with highly evocative art and enjoyable flavor text, but, really, that's much too much to ask, and to be honest I'm plenty satisfied with fun mediocre-even-in-casual-play junk like [autocard]Doom Cannon[/autocard]. (And I think it'll be d*mn hard to top the name Doomgape.)

However, I have a small quibble. Next time you all decide to charge ahead and be bold and print a card this cool, could you please give it the Legendary supertype, so that I can play it as my commander in EDH?

Many thanks! 5+/5.

P.S. It's really not too late to bring back [autocard multiverseid="2018"]doom counters[/autocard]. Just saying.

P.P.S. Doomgape + Enduring Renewal may not be the most efficient combo in Magic, but it's one of the most beautiful and naturalistic. (Contrast with Smokestack + Crucible of Worlds, which is depressingly industrial.)

It's a good card, but if you get hit by a wrath of god it's too late to play it, and if you play it before the wrath of god your opponent may choose to hold it back until you've played some of those cards you just drew.

That deck might take a bit longer to really get going, and this might be just the thing for when I have played most of my hand.

147373: Regal Force.author: Potrezebie
147373: Regal Force.text_parsed:
He’s the King of the 10 Minute Turn, and his groovy art celebrates how nature can succeed with synergistic strength in numbers, not just big claws or venomous fangs. My main cards can go down in any order, but they include Elvish Archdruid to get you the 7 mana, then Genesis Wave, Elvish Promenade or Ambush Commander to get him 10 creatures to draw 10 cards.

Once you start slapping down cards, while your friends go off to make popcorn and belittle your ancestry, with any luck, Soul of the Harvest will already be down, letting you draw another card each time a creature on the battlefield, or Karametra, God of Harvests (who is an indestructible creature now FOR SURE), will let you search for and deploy another white or green land, which of course instantly becomes an Elf due to Promenade.

It takes about as long to do all this as to make stove top popcorn, but when you’re done, of course, your Elvish Archdruid and Priest of Titania guys are now tapping for 18 mana each.

The salty hot garlic butter on this popcorn is Wellwisher, so you can tap your new Elf Friends for 18 life, and Omnath, Locus of Mana, who can absorb that extra muscle and block their Colossus of Akros, or probably somewhere in all that Card Draw Carnage Joraga Warcaller or Ezuri, Renegade Leader will have popped out, and you can say “winner doesn’t have to clean up the dishes”.

Don’t forget a Swiftfoot Boots which you can move from creature to creature as it hits the board for one mana each so they all have haste and hexproof. Warcaller can be kicked to +10 and he’ll make all your elves +10, or Ezuri can be tapped to make all your Elves +3 with trample. Partayyyyy Garth!!

I really like Glissa, the Traitor, but her individual prowess is getting obsolete in this Elf Deck of Synergy.

150986: Nip Gwyllion.author: Antsache
150986: Nip Gwyllion.text_parsed:
@Trollking

So most auras aren't legacy-playable, you say? Well, I never...
Seriously, though, everyone knows about the potential downsides of auras. Not everyone plays in formats where one or two-drop removal is common, though. Not to mention this card, Edge, and its supporting Liege all came from Eventide, and Shadowmoor block didn't have either of white's one-drop removal all-stars. Unmake seems more likely in that environment, and while that still hurts, you at least get to swing once or twice. For people using Dark Ritual, though, who clearly aren't playing in a limited environment... yeah, that's a lot of cards to commit to a single unprotected target.

If you know your play environment, though, as you should, especially if you're just playing the current standard, you can make plays like this that would seem absurd elsewhere. I wasn't around for Shadowmoor, unfortunately, so I can't say for certain whether it would actually be a good play, but I wouldn't be so quick to judge. If you pulled that with even one Edge in a draft, for instance, you'd probably be looking at a quick game.

150992: Helix Pinnacle.author: Treima
150992: Helix Pinnacle.text_parsed: An intriguing card, to be sure, but it requires 100 mana to be poured into it in order to win. I think even the fastest mana flood decks can't get 100 mana in anything less than 10 turns on average unless they use an infinite mana combo, and if you're using an infinite mana combo you could win a myriad of ways instantly instead of waiting for your next upkeep and giving your opponent the chance to play any number of enchantment destroyers that don't target a la Akroma's Vengeance. So you're waiting 10 turns and spending every last bit of mana you get into this one card while your opponent is setting up whatever combo or creature kill he's building up to. I'd say your odds of winning with this card are absolutely substantially worse in that case.

150992: Helix Pinnacle.author: Promatim
150992: Helix Pinnacle.text_parsed:
"All the turns you have nothing but mana?" Koopa, who are you playing that is letting you sit for ten turns with just mana?

I can start to think of cards to put with this, maybe a bant turtling deck, with some martial coupes, flutter of wings, cumber stones... but even still.

There are ways around the shroud, same way you get around prot. Global effects or spells that don't target a card will still affect Helix Pinnacle. It's limited, but there has to be something. Unfortunately, a single tranquility will wipe all your hard work away.

There are just so many nice 7-8 turn win condition decks out there, this card is useless.

You can't just go mana-accel, obviously. Even with explosive vegetation, elvish aberration, fyrnhorn elders, you're still hedging all your bets on one card that does nothing to the opponent. And you're vulnerable. Maybe a saproling deck with citanul hierophants could do it.

You'd have to do an all-out turtle/stall control deck, which would soak up a ton of your mana in defense. Enjoy your shaky win on turn eighteen.

150992: Helix Pinnacle.author: SpencerDub
150992: Helix Pinnacle.text_parsed:
@Kruggles: Each time you proliferate, you only add one more counter. Proliferating on the Pinnacle would only add one more tower counter-- it wouldn't double it.

Contagion Clasp proliferates for . Steady Progress proliferates for . Contagion Engine proliferates twice for , or per proliferation. None of these are as efficient as using the Pinnacle's own tower-building ability.

@ajpinton: "You can't Proliferate Helix Pinnacle due to it having shroud."

Check the reminder text for proliferate again. It doesn't target any permanents--instead, it asks you to choose any number of permanents. Choosing and targeting are two very different things. Rule 114.9a in the Comprehensive Rules backs me up:

"Just because an object or player is being affected by a spell or ability doesn’t make that
object or player a target of that spell or ability. Unless that object or player is identified by the
word “target” in the text of that spell or ability, or the rule for that keyword ability, it’s not a
target."
150992: Helix Pinnacle.text_posted:
@Kruggles: Each time you proliferate, you only add one more counter. Proliferating on the Pinnacle would only add one more tower counter-- it wouldn't double it.

[autocard]Contagion Clasp[/autocard] proliferates for [4]. [autocard]Steady Progress[/autocard] proliferates for [2U]. [autocard]Contagion Engine[/autocard] proliferates twice for [4], or [2] per proliferation. None of these are as efficient as using the Pinnacle's own tower-building ability.

@ajpinton: [i]"You can't Proliferate Helix Pinnacle due to it having shroud."[/i]

Check the reminder text for proliferate again. It doesn't [i]target[/i] any permanents--instead, it asks you to [i]choose[/i] any number of permanents. Choosing and targeting are two very different things. Rule 114.9a in the Comprehensive Rules backs me up:

[i]"Just because an object or player is being affected by a spell or ability doesn’t make that 
object or player a target of that spell or ability. Unless that object or player is identified by the 
word “target” in the text of that spell or ability, or the rule for that keyword ability, it’s not a 
target."[/i]

150992: Helix Pinnacle.author: MattLynn
150992: Helix Pinnacle.text_parsed: This will win in 15 turns with just a SINGLE Braid of Fire, assuming both cards come out on turn 1. is not impossible to make on turn 1. That is not even considering Doubling Season, either. With ANY other mana sources, it could be faster, especially in a / deck. In multiplayer, this is completely possible. I'm sure if that were your goal, a Sterling Grove, Greater Auramancy, Fountain Watch, Elspeth, Knight-Errant, Replenish, etc, would be good considerations. Ensnaring Bridge, Leyline of Sanctity, Moat, Norn's Annex, True Believer, etc. are also helpful with this theme. Bant & Naya colors love enchantments: Enchanted Evening, Hanna, Ship's Navigator . For that matter, so does Esper, if you consider Zur the Enchanter with Necropotence or even Ertai, the Corrupted. The enchantresses: Femeref Enchantress, Argothian Enchantress, Verduran Enchantress, Yavimaya Enchantress, Mesa Enchantress, Enchantress's Presence. Also Azorius First-Wing, Thaumatog, Phantatog are possibly at home in a deck like this...shout out to Lucent Luminid.

150992: Helix Pinnacle.author: casualhorror
150992: Helix Pinnacle.text_parsed:
This card wins naturally, when Helix Pinacle is played turn one, without missing land drops, at the beginning of your fifteenth turn with a total of 104 possible tower counters. (Wow! Faster than a 1/1 on turn 1 for {1} attacking each subsequent turn with no other creatures or spells getting played!) This is without you doing anything else other than straight hitting land drops and spending your mana. So here is a 'recommended' deck list:
4x Helix Pinnacle
4x Serum Powder
52 Forest

Our game plan is mulling until you have at least one Helix Pinnacle in hand,and then playing lands! You get bonus points if you get multiple Helix Pinnacles to one hundred before that fateful upkeep. (Hint: Get each one to the point where you can pay for the remaining tower counters of all of them at once!)


All joking aside, it is a decently hard to interact with win condition to use with infinite mana combos or complete lock outs in casual. Also, it is just plain fun to occasionally win with "bad" cards, especially if your friends are playing much more expensive decks. Fetch it with a tutor like Sterling Grove or Idyllic Tutor. Just make sure to have a Moment's Peace with Angel's Grace to get to through your opponent's final turns. Or perhaps this is your cruel win condition, without tutors or ramp, in a casual Orim's Chant/Silence Deck with Isochron Scepter.

Now you just need to choose/find your infinite combo or complete lock and your set for some Johnny fun! (I guess ramping works too, it just isn't as fun.)

150999: Slippery Bogle.author: Enchantment_Removal
150999: Slippery Bogle.text_parsed:
I got this Force of Willed on turn 0 during a Vintage tournament.

Oddly enough, despite how I built my deck, I did not draw into another creature for about the next 6-8 turns ( my opponent was playing a threshold control deck). What was he to think other than that him countering my Bogle was the right play?

So he was contemplating what to side in for game 2. He wasn't sure about anything- except the Bogle. So he showed me his Engineered Explosives that he sided exclusively for the Bogle he saw.

Game 2, I miraculously got him on the ropes thanks to a Punishment for 1 killing 3 Nimble Mongeese! I got to the point where my next attack would kill him, so what did he draw next turn to kill both of my 3 mana cost creatures? Yes, of course- he topdecked his Engineered Explosives and killed my dudes. That was the last of 5 turns and the match went to time. He won the first game and we drew on the second.

Slippery Bogle is serious F&%KING Business!
150999: Slippery Bogle.text_posted:

150999: Slippery Bogle.author: kiseki
150999: Slippery Bogle.text_parsed:
"This card originally had shroud, but that didn't allow its Aura (Favor of the Overbeing) to be played on it—a big no-no, as that's part of the fun of the one-drop hybrid creature. So we changed it to what R&D affectionately refers to as troll-shroud." - Mark Rosewater
http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/mr340

I love that the card got a boost due to the fact that the obvious design made it unfun. I would play 8 if they made it a companion. My personal favorite aura is Verdant Embrace, and this is a great choice for it.

151060: Cauldron Haze.author: Mode
151060: Cauldron Haze.text_parsed:
I'm the third person to wonder about the community rating and give this card 4/5.
It won't be able to save x/1 creatures of course, but aside from that you can either only save one orall creatures on your side with toughness 2 or more. And this might either happen through combat damage or any m^ass removal effects.

Since you can choose to give this effect to any creature, it might be useful in teamplay as well, and you could even save an opponent's creature if it comes handy.

And all that at instant speed for a colorless and a hybrid mana, that's seriously not a bad thing.

151060: Cauldron Haze.author: Amaroq64
151060: Cauldron Haze.text_parsed:
In response to the guy who said it's rated so low because of Cauldron of Souls:

I don't understand why that's so. You don't necessarily need to use it on every creature you have for it to be worth the mana cost.

Undying Evil gives one creature Undying for one black mana. If you only give two creaturs Persist with this card, it's the equivalent of two Undying Evils. Except it's Persist instead of Undying. But still useful in decks where you want stuff to die and come back.

I'm planning on making a Proliferate Infect Deck around Core Prowler and Throne of Geth, and putting in playable sets of Undying Evil, Cauldron Haze, and other things to help me get my Core Prowlers back so I can sacrifice them again.

151060: Cauldron Haze.author: BastianQoU
151060: Cauldron Haze.text_parsed:
This looks like it can be a secondary finisher in a Blood Seeker/Suture Priest deck I'm building.

6 turn: cast Alliance of Arms (after having 2-3 of either BS or SP on the field)
7 turn: cast this, targeting all their soldiers. Cast Curse of Death's Hold

Doesn't really beat out having the curse out earlier, since they'd have a chance to attack with all the soldiers first. Intangible Virtue would prevent that though. Still, this is all assuming the opponents can survive after AoA is cast in the first place. Stranger things have happened..

151060: Cauldron Haze.author: Brawler_1337
151060: Cauldron Haze.text_parsed:
I friggin' love this card, both on paper and in practice. On paper, you can save your entire board from a wrath effect and troll the hell out of your opponent. In practice, I used this in my Karador EDH deck with Solemn Simulacrum and Altar's Reap to reap serious value off of sacking one creature. It went like this:

1. During the end of the turn of the guy before me, cast this targeting Sad Robot , giving it persist.

2. Cast Altar's Reap sacking Sad Robot, drawing a card, searching for a basic after he persisted back, and then drawing two more cards.

3. Draw for turn. Somewhere in the middle of all this card draw, I drew into Skullclamp.

4. Play Skullclamp and hook it up to my now 1/1 Sad Robot. Draw three more cards.

There's so much this card and its big brother Cauldron of Souls can do in a deck like mine. Use it on Sylvan Primordial and then sac Primordial to Greater Good to blow more stuff up, ramp more Forests, draw 6, and ditch three creatures I need in the yard for Karador plays? Yes, please! Give Ashen Rider persist and sac him off to exile two or three more permanents? Hell yeah! Use with Phyrexian Altar to get mana and keep your creatures? I like the sound of that. I think this card deserves a higher rating than it has, because the utility you can get out of giving your board of creatures persist is quite amazing.

I'm giving it a 4/5 now, since it's not bonkers enough to get a 4.5/5, but I would definitely recommend it for decks with lots of ETB/LTB triggers and sac outlets.

151068: Riverfall Mimic.author: billpasdmf
151068: Riverfall Mimic.text_parsed:
A little unsure about the whole Clout of the Dominus thing. The wording on this guy very specifically says it becomes 3/3, not gets +1/+2. My thoughts are that w/ Clout you're turning it into a 4/3 shroud haste creature w/ the little inconvenience of the "becomes 3/3" Soooo, you're going to end up w/ a 3/3 unblockable haste shroud mimic that will become 4/3 at the end of the turn. Next turn you cast another U/R spell and its going to be 3/3 again not 5/5. The whole "becomes" thing works both ways kiddies; not just the way you want it too.

The key word on this card is "unblockable." Having a couple 3/3 unblockables every turn is really fun. I got these guys in a deck w/ Crackleburr, gelectrode, and some other nasties as well. BIG FUN!!

Not dismissing Clout because giving something that weak shroud is always a good idea when you've got such great combo potential.

151068: Riverfall Mimic.author: Styny
151068: Riverfall Mimic.text_parsed:
so heres how this works with clout of the dominus

you cast clout of the dominus. it goes on the stack. Casting triggers the mimics ability, that goes on the stack. The mimics ability resolves first, its becomes a 3/3 unblockable. then clout of the dominus resolves. it enchants the mimic, giving it +2/+2, haste and shroud. Its a 5/5 haste shroud unblockable. now, if i were to cast another U/R spell, it would be a 3/3 haste shroud unblockable.

so YES it does become a 5/5, but ONLY on the turn you play the enchantment. after that, its back to 3/3 land whenever you cast another U/R spell

151068: Riverfall Mimic.text_parsed: Okay, according to the rules section in the oracle, even after you put a Clout on it, if you were to play a spell that is both blue and red, the Mimic's BASE power and toughness become 3/3. 151068: Riverfall Mimic.author: DaMaster012
151068: Riverfall Mimic.text_parsed:
Drop a Clout of the Dominus this guy, start the four-turn clock; lol as opponents without enchantment/shroud removal totally rage.

If for some reason they're still live by turn six, drop a Rage Reflection; there aren't many things that top a shrouded, hasty, double-striking creature that you can turn into a 5/5 unblockable every turn.

I give this card a 4/5; it synergies wonderfully with the right deck, but it's pretty much a smaller Wee Dragonauts that can't be blocked and doesn't get bonuses from non-static abilities, and is particularly susceptible to spot removal and burn without something like Clout of the Dominus to protect it. Though while probably not the best stand-alone Mimic, it works great with an Izzet deck like mine that's built around aggressive, hard-to-block rushes while constantly playing spells. And with the aforementioned enchantment it's a real force to be reckoned with; I've had people drop two Oblivion Rings on them just to get rid of that kind of power. For anybody whose fond of rolling U/R aggro decks, I could easily recommend getting a playset of these... and of Clouts.

151068: Riverfall Mimic.author: DarkonCrack
151068: Riverfall Mimic.text_parsed:
For those of you who question what his power/toughness is with Clout of the Dominus and what happens after that turn and etc. I reference comprehensive rule 613.3 Go look it up if your interested, but to break it down, everything is applied in layers, not everything in timestamps.

So, Riverfall Mimic is usually 2/1. You cast Riverfall and enchant it with the Clout, while Clout is on the stack, it's a 3/3. Then, Clout hits it and it gets +1/+1 and +1/+1 (because it's both colors) therefore becoming a 5/5.

At the end of your turn, he reverts back to a 2/1 that's getting +2/+2 (so it's a 4/3). Now, whenever you cast a spell that's both blue and red, any spell, it becomes a 3/3 and then the +2/+2 is added to that. And, if you cast another spell that's blue and red, it will STILL be a 5/5 because it becoming a 3/3 doesn't add +1/+2, it sets it's power and toughness.

So yeah. Just a tidbit for ya'll to ponder. 2/1, 4/3, and 5/5 are your Riverfall/Clout options. Which, if you don't know, is still retarded good for a 2 mana creature.

Also, another thing to consider, though not as good, Magefire Wings.

3 mana for only creature hosing is rather expensive when you have cards like path to exile and doom blade.

Still, path is on the expensive side (at least 5 dollars for one, and will only increase in price. This is like 1-2 dollars for a playset) and doom blade can't hit black creatures and won't phase regenerators or darksteel colossus, and also nuke persist/unearth creatures, so this has its uses. It certainly saw a lot of play when lorwyn was in standard, but now it's pretty much stuck to being a cheap alternative for casual decks. White has no reason to run this with path around, and black probably wants to save 1-2 mana by running cheaper removal spells and accept the drawbacks of nuking a smaller selection of creatures.

151083: Unmake.author: SleetFox
151083: Unmake.text_parsed: I love thorough answers like this. It's somewhat expensive and is virtually unplayable in almost any multicolored deck that isn't Orzhov-colored, but protection and shroud are the only ways to survive this, which no single-target removal spell can get around. Path to Exile is largely the better card, but I feel much more secure with my Unmake in my hand than I do with my Path to Exile, since you don't have to be quite as judicious with it. There is also the point in the game where you have three lands out but it's too early to let your opponent get an extra land without suffering a noticeable disadvantage, where Unmake is unquestionably the better card. Sure, that point doesn't last long, but you can't expect everything to be as good as the second-best single-creature removal spell ever made, can you?

151083: Unmake.author: raptorman333
151083: Unmake.text_parsed:
@Kruggles: that's like saying "haha" with a reviver deck and Pull from Eternity
strictly indicates a whole list of conditions--rarity, versatility, efficiency (usually having to do with effect vs. mana cost). To be strictly, it would have to do the same exact thing as printed on another card (like Time Walk vs. Temporal Manipulation--but not Time Warp because that targets a player and can be either Swerved or target a teammate).
To be strictly better, it would have to do any one or combination of the following:

the exact same thing as another card, but either give you more options along with it at the same mana cost and/or just simply cost less mana and/or require less restrictive mana (versatility; efficiency).

reduce rarity to lower resale costs or move into common rarity for use in pauper decks. (rarity)

No one stated that this was strictly better than Terminate other than you because it isn't. The mana costs despite one being lower than the other are restrictive--I can only play terminate in a deck that has a mana base for red and black and i can only play unmake in a deck that has a mana base for either white or black. The option to have unmake in a mono white or a mono black deck does not offset for the increase in mana.
Strike 1 against "strictly"

The cards don't do the same thing--one puts the creature into the graveyard while the other removes it from the game. If i wanted to steal my opponent's creature from the graveyard--something frequently seen in black (e.g. lilianna vess, rise from the grave, etc.) I now can't with unmake. However, unmake has a larger range of creatures that it can remove, like 6cmc elementals from Lorwyn and eldrazi that leave the graveyard or indestructible creatures that can't be destroyed.
Strike 2 against "strictly"

you and a load of others on this database egregiously through around the word "strictly" and you're wrong and should stop. no wonder you have half a star on your comment--the lowest possible rating.

151089: Flickerwisp.author: kiseki
151089: Flickerwisp.text_parsed:
This is my favorite white card of all time. People have already mentioned the efficiency and a few comparisons so I will get right to my favorite combos:

Tokens! Maul Splicer, Cloudgoat Ranger, Chancellor of the Forge
Resources! Soul Warden, Suture Priest, Elvish Visionary, Farhaven Elf
Removal! Acidic Slime, Exclusion Ritual, Sparkmage Apprentice, Furystoke Giant, Flametongue Kavu
Shenanigans! Flicker another Flickerwisp and then deprive your opponent of something then need next turn, use miraculous recovery to do these things instantly, remove a blocker, kill a token, force an additional bounce on a bounce land, get your permanents back, (re)move auras...

The efficiency is insane. for a 3/1 flier AND two 3/3 golems, or AND exile a nonland permanent forever or AND double all your creatures again. Let me assure you, when you play this kind of deck, and start flickering your own 'Wisps, your opponents will respond, and you will have one in your graveyard by the time you start thinking about casting Miraculous Recovery. You might think Momentary Blink is an appropriate card, but it pales in comparison because you don't also get a body with it.
When you build around this, don't forget to include the Glimmerpoint Stags and the Galepowder Mages.

151089: Flickerwisp.author: Asmodi0000
151089: Flickerwisp.text_parsed:
Ignoring the hundreds of uses this has, it's a 3/1 flyer for 3, which isn't bad. In fact, if you bounce back one of your tapped lands, it's virtually a 3/1 for 2, which is great.

Now, we can take a look at all the other things it can do.

1. Freak out your opponent with its art
2. Can shield your eyes from the glare of the sun.
3. Can be turned into pulp, than recycled into a completely different piece of paper
4. Tear it up and use it as confetti.
5. Use it as a proxy for another card.
6. Fling it to create a diversion so you can place down a Cheatyface.

And it also has a readily abuseable ability that can reset planeswalkers, kill tokens, retrigger ETB effects, untap lands, remove blockers, destroy auras, unequip equipment, return creatures to your control, protect things from mass removal, and the list goes on.

4. Tear it up and use it as confetti.
5. Use it as a proxy for another card.
6. Fling it to create a diversion so you can place down a [autocard]Cheatyface[/autocard].

And it also has a readily abuseable ability that can reset planeswalkers, kill tokens, retrigger ETB effects, untap lands, remove blockers, destroy auras, unequip equipment, return creatures to your control, protect things from mass removal, and the list goes on.

151089: Flickerwisp.author: Havrekjex
151089: Flickerwisp.text_parsed:
The first time I saw this card, I saw a poor man's Restoration Angel. I thought that it was hopelessly inferior because it doesn't have flash, and the exiled permanent doesn't return until EOT. Then it dawned on me... any permanent. While it isn't as effective as Resto and Cloudshift for abusing your own ETB triggers, and it can't save a creature mid-combat, it has about a million other applications. This is based on someone else's work, props to the guy who wrote this on a certain Internet forum.

1. Cast it to reuse a positive ETB trigger on one of your creatures (Thragtusk, Blade Splicer), or a negative one on one of your opponent's creatures (Phyrexian Dreadnought).
2. Cast it to untap one of your own creatures after attacking with it.
3. Cast it targeting your own land to untap it, basically making it cost one less mana that you can use on something at instant speed (Path to Exile and Lighting Bolt ready in your opponent's turn).
4. Cast it to remove a blocker.
5. Cast it to kill one of your opponent's creature tokens.
6. Cast it to remove/reset counters;
__a) targeting an opposing Æther Vial, Engineered Explosives, Chalice of the Void, Protean Hydra, etc. to remove all counters from it.
__b) targeting a planeswalker to reset its number of loyalty counters.
__c) targeting your own permanent to remove upkeep counters (Jötun Grunt), vanishing counters (Deadwood Treefolk), fading counters, -1/-1 counters (Kitchen Finks), +1/+1 counters (Geralf's Messenger).
__d) targeting your own permanent to restore counters (Triskelion, Serrated Arrows).
7. Cast it targeting your Oblivion Ring or Phyrexian Revoker to switch targets when it comes back.
8. Cast it targeting another Flickerwisp you own so that when the second comes back, it removes something for the entire next turn.

For many of the cards mentioned as examples, there are literally hundreds of others with similar functions. Yet, all this is just the tip of the iceberg compared to what you can do with it if you've also got Æther Vial. Instant speed breaks this card in half.

Probably one of my favourite cards ever. 5/5.

151095: Nettle Sentinel.author: Necrokeryx
151095: Nettle Sentinel.text_parsed:
There are three 2/2 creatures in green for one mana. (four if you count an unglued card, but I will not)

This is by far the most reliable card for green aggro. Of the other two, Pouncing Jaguar puts you behind the mana curve, and Ghazbán Ogre is arguably pretty good as well, but can easily backfire on you.

This card's drawback is more like a balance factor to it's other ability, as if you're playing green aggro with green's famous combat tricks, it will pretty much have vigilance during the turns that really matter. This is an amazing card for green aggro. It's kind of surprising how few 2/2 creatures green has for one mana, being the color of huge, effecient creatures.

In case you're curious, Ghazbán Ogress is the unglued card.

151099: Nightsky Mimic.author: Kirbster
151099: Nightsky Mimic.text_parsed: This guy was nuts. Everyone loves to imagine the mimics along with their demigod enchantments, but he really didn't need it. Playing a Nightsky Mimic on turn two often heralds a quick path to a brutal victory: a 4/4 flyer attacking every turn is nothing to sneeze at. Just keep blasting blockers (Mortify, Pillory of the Sleepless) and dropping support (Stillmoon Cavalier or just more mimics) and your opponent's life will bottom out in short order.

151113: Phosphorescent Feast.author: Mode
151113: Phosphorescent Feast.text_parsed:
Ok, let's think of a good use for this card. (Although in this case i'm merely looking for an optimized effect of it)
Khalni Hydra would make the best combination with this card.
And to get a better chance for lots of mana symbols, you could indeed put this in a deck that just uses these green creatures that exclusively require green mana to pay (Leatherback Baloth, Rushwood Elemental, Primalcrux or the Hydra), then this card can net for 20 or more life.

But it's still questionable whether you need lifegain in such a deck.

Generally speaking it's still expensive unreliable life-gain for five mana that does not even have instant-speed - and if it's the only card in your hand it's just a dead card.

Overall it's a rather bad card imo.

I think it could have been interesting for only if a cap for the life gain would have been included as well.

4.5/5

151113: Phosphorescent Feast.author: tcollins
151113: Phosphorescent Feast.text_parsed:
Chroma could have been such a great mechanic for {G}...instead a {G} player playing this card now loses all elements of card advantage, they reveal their hand (or at least part of it), which really gets rid of the 'guessing game' of not knowing what your opponent has...this wouldn't be such a problem in other colours like {U} or {B} where card drawing can replenish your hand quite quickly, but in {G} you have very limited card drawing.


They could've gone the other generic {G} spell route for promoting a new set, they could've had

{4}{G}{G} - Miniscule Overrun - Instant
"Reveal any number of cards in your hand, put a 1/1 green insect token into play for each green mana symbol in their converted mana costs"

It would've been fantastic...although I think the sample I gave may be a bit aggressively costed.
151113: Phosphorescent Feast.text_posted:
[i]Chroma[/i] could have been such a great mechanic for {G}...instead a {G} player playing this card now loses all elements of card advantage, they reveal their hand (or at least part of it), which really gets rid of the 'guessing game' of not knowing what your opponent has...this wouldn't be such a problem in other colours like {U} or {B} where card drawing can replenish your hand quite quickly, but in {G} you have very limited card drawing.


They could've gone the other generic {G} spell route for promoting a new set, they could've had

151113: Phosphorescent Feast.author: monkeymonk42
151113: Phosphorescent Feast.text_parsed:
Chroma is an incredibly dumb keyword. Don't get me wrong, i like the idea and i think there are some good chroma cards, (a big fan of primalcrux) but do they really need the keyword? A keyword is supposed to reduce text on a card, and there isn't a single chroma card that doesn't have a large amount of text behind the word chroma explaining what it does.

If you just saw a card and it said chroma on it, what would that even mean? It wouldn't mean anything at all without more text.

The fact that this card was originally printed in future sight without the keyword proves that they could have printed all chroma cards without it and it would have been fine, magic players are smart enough to notice patterns and we would have noticed a "mana symbol matters" pattern without this keyword.

151114: Rise of the Hobgoblins.author: jonrds
151114: Rise of the Hobgoblins.text_parsed:
Combos amazingly with reconnaissance. You can attack with all your tokens and pull any that would die out of combat after blockers have been declared, so the rest of the tokens get through. Then, once damage has been done, pull out the rest of your creatures, essentially giving them vigilance.

This isn't even counting the first strike ability, which combos stupidly well with reconnaisance, since you an deal first strike damage and then remove creatures from combat.

Helm of the Ghastlord

You wanna know why this cycle of auras is my favorite EVER?

Transguild Courier {4}

Lifelink, first strike, double strike, trample, indestructible, flying, deathtouch, vigilance, shroud, haste
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, draw a card.
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, that player discards a card.
This creature can't be blocked.
All creatures able to block this creature do so.
R/W: This creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
24/24

151124: Stream Hopper.author: SkyknightXi
151124: Stream Hopper.text_parsed: For all the idea of losing half his body through the Aurora, this is actually based on the fachan from Scottish legend. The fachan was a goblin with but one of everything. One eye, one tooth, one arm, one leg, possibly one finger, etc. Despite its withered appearance, its arm was incredibly strong, and it had a fondness for wrecking orchards by swinging a vicious iron chain around. Its head bore a mane of black feathers and an impossible-to-bend tuft of hair, and its mouth was extremely wide. Supposedly, just seeing a fachan could cause one to suffer a heart attack from sheer horror. (Too bad this was in the wrong colors for fear...)
151124: Stream Hopper.text_posted: For all the idea of losing half his body through the Aurora, this is actually based on the fachan from Scottish legend. I really like the cheap flash ability and the buffs, too, but I don't like how the third ability doesn't suggest having more than 1 Mindwrack in play, such as the Creakwood Liege's third ability does. Sure, the buffs stack, but the flash ability doesn't. All in all, I think he is really good, but there are definitely better lieges.

Edit: After having played with Conflux and Alara Reborn, the Mindwrack Liege has definitely moved up in my opinion. 151132: Mindwrack Liege.author: Donovan_Fabian
151132: Mindwrack Liege.text_parsed:
I like this card, but I also feel its in the middle of the lieges. I think balefire may be the best, followed by this one. The problem with it is look at its cmc, at 6 I can play several better cards for 5, such as deus of calamity. Secondly, a lot of blue creatures do not cost huge amounts, and red creatures don't usually either, or if they do probably not to much beyond 4 in the first place. Now its true you can "flash" block, or have some huge creature in your deck to put out with this, but what happens if you draw those big creatures and don't have your liege in hand? I wouldn't want to have that high a mana curve and rely on the liege to get them out. Mayael I feel is a much better card, because even though it costs 6 and have to tap, it can also be used on opponents turn and searches your top 5 cards.

151132: Mindwrack Liege.author: Rendin
151132: Mindwrack Liege.text_parsed:
@StormCroww

A creature is a certain color if it has one or more of those mana symbols in its casting cost (or it says that it's that color, as is the case of Transguild Courier, etc.) So a card like Prince of Thralls for example, is affected by things that have effect on blue cards, red cards, and black cards.

If the card said "You may put a blue and/or red permanent from your hand into play" then it would mean you could put TWO cards into play for the activation cost, not just one. Hopefully this clears up any misunderstanding you may have had with the card's text.

151132: Mindwrack Liege.author: DaMaster012
151132: Mindwrack Liege.text_parsed:
Honestly, and this may surprise some people, I was really disappointed by this guy.

After seeing the other outstanding conflicting-color lieges like the pyromaniac Balefire Liege and the nightmarishly overpowered Deathbringer Liege, I was expecting this liege to have similar 'get more for your spells' effect, like letting you draw a card whenever you played a blue spell and giving you the option for some extra burn when you played a red spell; essentially giving you a free Electrolyze with every spell in the same way Balefire Liege gives you a free Lightning Helix with every spell and Deathbringer Liege allots a free creature-only Mortify with ever spell. It's would've given some much needed extra 'umph' that decks built around playing lots of multicolor spells sorely need (like mine). Instead, we got this...

I know I'm strictly basing my judgement mostly off of what I expect to get from and how well I fit things into my trigger-happy deck, but this guy just doesn't synergize like I hoped he would. His ability to let you drop any creature for only four mana was a nice thought, but I never really got that much use from it since the only four creatures in my deck that cost more than four mana were the two of these I had and my two Niv-Mizzets, which wasn't nearly as liberating of my mana as adding those two Urza's Filters were, which made all my multicolored spells cheaper to cast. And though his creature buff was great, it didn't augment their offensive capabilities as much as replacing them with two Rage Reflections did.

I do see potential for this guy, like in a suspend deck that's going to have a plethora of massive creatures that he, along with Jhoira of the Ghitu and all the time-bending cards in that block let you drop ridiculously easy, with a slight buff to boot. (See this Deep-Sea Kraken and this Greater Gargadon that both cost ten mana to play? I just dropped them, counter-proof, for four mana each. You mad?) So I'm not totally discounting this guy, but I'm still dismayed that he doesn't make a name for himself among the already limited number of cards meant to bring unity to Magic's most conflicting colors.

3 out of 5, just because most disappointment is still that vast. Maybe if they do the Ravnica revisit like it's rumored that they will after Innistrad, we'll get an Izzet Guild-master capable of performing what I hoped this guy would've done.

151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.author: MattyDrac
151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.text_parsed: Hi everyone. If you put Fire of Power onto Ashling, the Extinguisher and you tapped it to deal one damage to target player. Would it still cause a player to sacrifice a creature. It came up in a game I was playing recently, and I got told that the player would only sacrifice a creature when Ashling deals combat damage as it states on his card. I was told that tapping the card and using the power of Fire ability to deal one damage to target player isn't dealing combat damge and as such doesn't cause the targeted player to sacrifice a card? Could someone please clarify this for me? thanks :)
151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.text_posted: Hi everyone. If you put Fire of Power onto Ashling, the Extinguisher and you tapped it to deal one damage to target player. Would it still cause a player to sacrifice a creature. It came up in a game I was playing recently, and I got told that the player would only sacrifice a creature when Ashling deals combat damage as it states on his card. I was told that tapping the card and using the power of Fire ability to deal one damage to target player isn't dealing combat damge and as such doesn't cause the targeted player to sacrifice a card? Could someone please clarify this for me? thanks :)

151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.author: adrian.malacoda
151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.text_parsed:
@MattyDrac

Damage from abilities such as "Deal 1 damage to target creature or player" is not combat damage and will not trigger this ability. Combat damage is damage done by creature combat. This ability only triggers if Ashling attacks the opponent and deals any damage. Unfortunately Power of Fire, while thematically related to Ashling the Extinguisher, doesn't work for the purpose of triggering her ability.

As stated elsewhere in the comment thread Whispersilk Cloak will make her unblockable, allowing her to deal direct combat damage.

Also, this won't kill Progenitus because it has to target him.
151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.text_posted:
@MattyDrac

Damage from abilities such as "Deal 1 damage to target creature or player" is not combat damage and will not trigger this ability. Combat damage is damage done by creature combat. This ability only triggers if Ashling attacks the opponent and deals any damage. Unfortunately [autocard]Power of Fire[/autocard], while thematically related to Ashling the Extinguisher, doesn't work for the purpose of triggering her ability.

As stated elsewhere in the comment thread [autocard]Whispersilk Cloak[/autocard] will make her unblockable, allowing her to deal direct combat damage.

Also, this won't kill Progenitus because it has to target him.

151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.author: Enelysios
151137: Ashling, the Extinguisher.text_parsed:
A lot of people seem to be ignoring the fact that she does not destroy creatures, she makes your opponent sacrifice them. That's a big distinction. She will remove indestructible creatures, and they cannot be regenerated. Sadly she does target still, so shroud and hexproof get annoying.

Even still, she is an amazing general for EDH. She is cheap (By general standards.) and mana-efficient, begging for equipment. (I run her with a full complement of swords, a whispersilk cloak and Basilisk Collar) Plus, that art alone is a reason to play her, maybe my favorite art on a black creature. I also run a glaring spotlight in the deck now, and with that out, shroud is basically the only way to keep her from killing your general.

151139: Light from Within.author: Callipsa
151139: Light from Within.text_parsed:
It had a worse rating for several reasons, those include:
1) 4 mana drop, when most white weenies only have 1 or 2 for there colored mana cost, largley making it obsolete for the extra mana (in comparison to glorious anthem or shared triumph).

2) Most 4 mana cards have game changing effects, this could change the game, but would have a hard time doing so on its own, and before you mention stuff like oversoul of dusk or dawn elemental there are far better cards to combo those with, and besides, you will basically never find those cards in a good weenie deck, which is what this was made for.

3) This is the big one: Most weenie decks (good ones) have a large quantity of tokens, becuase if you ran all creature cards to try and zerg your enemy, you would fail pretty bad VS board effects. Becuase most weenie decks run lots of tokens, this does nothing. Big one right there.

It had a worse rating for several reasons, those include:
1) 4 mana drop, when most white weenies only have 1 or 2 for there colored mana cost, largley making it obsolete for the extra mana (in comparison to glorious anthem or [autocard]shared triumph[/autocard]).

2) Most 4 mana cards have game changing effects, this could change the game, but would have a hard time doing so on its own, and before you mention stuff like [autocard]oversoul of dusk[/autocard] or [autocard]dawn elemental[/autocard] there are far better cards to combo those with, and besides, you will basically never find those cards in a good weenie deck, which is what this was made for.

3) This is the big one: Most weenie decks (good ones) have a large quantity of tokens, becuase if you ran all creature cards to try and zerg your enemy, you would fail pretty bad VS  board effects. Becuase most weenie decks run lots of tokens, this does nothing. Big one right there.

151149: Fire at Will.author: DoctorKenneth
151149: Fire at Will.text_parsed:
Okay, first of all, Joseph, that approach is not a good way to compare cards. By that logic, Shock would be better than Flame Javelin because three Shocks do more damage for the same mana. This is one card. Using three cards does not compare to the clear advantage of using one card. The ability to divide damage and kill multiple attackers or blockers is a clear benefit over straight burn. Also, the bolt wasn't in the format at the time to compare this to.

That said, you and Treima are correct in that there ARE better options out there. Hail of Arrows and Arrow Volley Trap are better (though not STRICTLY better), if only limited to attackers. Ballista Squad is the same thing with legs. Arc Lightning is this without the restriction, but without the possibility of playing it in mono-white. Rock Slide has a no-flying restriction, and is also stuck in red. So, we have no direct comparison, but generally this comes out a little lacking.

In short, not worthless. Underwhelming and outclassed in places, but not worthless.

[autocard]Rock Slide[/autocard] has a no-flying restriction, and is also stuck in red. So, we have no direct comparison, but generally this comes out a little lacking.

In short, not worthless. Underwhelming and outclassed in places, but not worthless.

151151: Overbeing of Myth.author: Donovan_Fabian
151151: Overbeing of Myth.text_parsed: Overbeing + reliquary tower + thought reflection on following turn.  At least make your opponent work for it.  You can play a diplomatic immunity on her as well and then just reserve cards in your hand to keep her power up.  Even better if you have cards with forecast.  The way to look at it is overbeing of myth is a creature version of jace beleren, you can't reach the ultimate mill 20 off library that jace has, but you also never have to let your opponent also draw a card, getting an extra card draw every upkeep plus a creature that can at least chump block if you need it too.  Only problem I have with this card is that it should have been 1+ cards in hand, because if you have to use up your cards you kill the creature too.  Its best to use cards to get her power up a bit that will keep her in play if you run out of cards, like murkfiend liege, jund charm, mayael's aria, or her own enchantment favor of the overbeing.

151151: Overbeing of Myth.author: Zulp
151151: Overbeing of Myth.text_parsed:
She's just sort of boring, unfortunately. There's not a lot you can do with her unless you use her in a dedicated drawing deck. Bringing you up to two cards a turn isn't enough to ensure that she's big enough to either beat face or survive burn, but if the designers had made her draw you two extra cards a turn, she probably would have been overpowered. If you put her in a deck made to use her, I suppose she'd work, but she's not flexible enough to interest me.

Which is a damn shame, really, because her flavor and colors rock. 3.5/5.

151151: Overbeing of Myth.author: LordRandomness
151151: Overbeing of Myth.text_parsed:
A few quick tips:
- Gush gives +4/+4 for no mana cost
- Meloku, the Clouded Mirror lets you sweep your untapped land for +1/+1 and a token per land. (Sweep keyword spells aren't on-colour for some reason =/)
- Sturmgeist is Overbeings 5 through 8 if they connect. For that matter, stacking these guys is always fun.

In general, a card that returns things to your hand as a cost tends to be good. Scryb Ranger is a nice partner once you've got enough land drops, giving you pseudo-vigilance and keeping the Overbeing nice and large, with the option to return a forest on your opponent's turn as well if need be.

151153: Gift of the Deity.author: Donovan_Fabian
151153: Gift of the Deity.text_parsed: In some ways its more important to consider that your other creatures are all getting through any time you attack with the one that has gift of the deity attached to it.  Your deity of scars enchanted with gift of the deity attacks, along with say a creakwood liege and a myriad of worm tokens, and your opponent must have their creatures block the deity who will just regenerate, removing all their creatures, and taking damage from the other attackers.  Its a step up from the prized unicorn, whom as anyone can tell you who has ever enchanted a branchwood armor on one, can be a really destructive play, trading several creatures for 1.  Since one of the colors is green it also makes perfect sense to have giant growths, that can do away with more creatures and keep yours alive at the same time, or simply give the creature first strike with something like rakeclaw gargantuan.

151153: Gift of the Deity.author: Dr.Pingas
151153: Gift of the Deity.text_parsed: I love the over exaggeration in the comments. Under no rules past or present is this as good as plague wind, and I say that as an old old player that learned the game on thicket lure. The issue is death touch. Its always always under every combat damage rule only been able to kill up to X blocking creatures, where x is its power. You need to do the damage to get the kill, unlike thicket that kills after combat regardless. So on a 1/1 BG creature, you kill up to 3 untapped creatures defending player controls. Not saying its awful, has its uses, but be reasonable
151153: Gift of the Deity.text_posted: I love the over exaggeration in the comments. 151153: Gift of the Deity.author: SirLibraryEater
151153: Gift of the Deity.text_parsed:
Steel of the Godhead
Helm of the Ghastlord
Fists of the Demigod
Runes of the Deus
Shield of the Oversoul
Edge of the Divinity
Gift of the Deity
Favor of the Overbeing
Clout of the Dominus
Scourge of the Nobilis
You wanna know why this cycle of auras is my favorite EVER?
Let's say we enchant 5-color creature, I don't know, Transguild Courier, with all of these.
Here's what you get.

Transguild Courier {4}

Lifelink, first strike, double strike, trample, indestructible, flying, deathtouch, vigilance, shroud, haste
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, draw a card.
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, that player discards a card.
This creature can't be blocked.
All creatures able to block this creature do so.
R/W: This creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
24/24

151154: Dominus of Fealty.author: UltimaCenturion
151154: Dominus of Fealty.text_parsed:
Sorry, HydroGoose, you can't negate creatures. You can essence scatter him (watch out, because if they are smart, they're running swerves, declarations of naughts, etc.), cancel him, broken dreams him, even cursecatcher or familiar ruse him, but NOT negate.
And spark spray is 1 damage! I looked it up! What good does that do against a 4/4 flier?
What you need against this guy is board wipe!
If you throw green in a deck with him, though (try vivid lands to get this guy out easier), try "Ooze Garden." Or "Scarland Thrinax." Maybe "Mercy Killing" (I make your thing into my own tokens!) If you make a highlander or non-standard with him in it (and other "control your enemy's stuff" stuff), you can throw in that one old enchantment that makes your enemies sac creatures when you sac one! Take a creature, sac it, destroy an enemy creature. What's not to like?

151155: Edge of the Divinity.author: humor_love
151155: Edge of the Divinity.text_parsed:
@ AXER:

That's not a combo; that's doing what the card designers told you to do.

Putting Fallen Angel, Grave Pact, and some Reassembling Skeleton cards into play together is a combo.

That is: it's not obvious, meaning that you have to use some amount of creativity of your own, yet it works like crazy.

Putting Priest of Titania and a bunch of other elf cards into play is not a combo. Playing Edge of Divinity on a creature that is black and white is not a combo. Playing a black and white enchantment on Nightsky Mimic, and then attacking with Mimic, is not a combo. Those plays take as much thought or creativity as putting Mountain cards into a deck with Fireball cards. Doing those things is just following steps that have been laid out for you by others.

I am not insinuating that AXER or any other player is unintelligent, stupid, dumb, or bad at Magic. I am explaining the difference between putting together cards that have their combinations literally spelled out for players, on the one hand, and putting together cards that work great together despite the fact that such pairings or combinations are not explicitly and preemptively spelled out on and designed into the cards by the game designers.

While it doesn't take a genius to put Fallen Angel, Grave Pact, and Reassembling Skeleton together, such a combination of cards is not immediately obvious (it takes a liiiitle bit of thinking, at least - beyond simply reading and comprehending the cards); and the combination of the three (or any two of the three) is not made explicit in either the rules texts (and/or the colors) of the cards (e.g. Edge of Divinity/Nightsky Mimic), the 'types' of the cards (e.g. artifacts, or elves and other tribes), or both (e.g. Priest of Titania).

151165: Battlegate Mimic.author: WotC_ErikL
151165: Battlegate Mimic.text_parsed:
Erik's Random card 6/8/2011
This is part of a cycle of Mimics in Eventide.
Design and Development each took its time trying to figure out what this cycle should be.

It started off in design as a hate card:

1(r/w)(r/w)
First strike Whenever CARDNAME is the target of a blue or black spell, draw a card.
2/2

Then it became a reward for your colors

1(r/w)(r/w)
First strike Whenever CARDNAME is the target of a red or white spell, draw a card.
2/2

Then there was an attempt at linking it to the mutual allied color in the color wheel:

Whenever you play a green spell, you may pay 2 to draw a card.

That was nice with SSE drafts, since Shadowmoor had both Green White and Red Green cards and decks. However it did not make a lot of sense in Eventide packs.

At that point it entered development. Matt Place, the lead developer of the set, wanted to try something simpler at common:

3(r/w)(r/w)
When cardname attacks it gets +3/+0 until end of turn.
1/5

However hybrid cards can be played in a deck that only has one of the colors. You could have no red at all, and your card is 3WW 1/5 When cardname attacks it gets +4/+0 until end of turn; a 5/5 attacker for 5 as a white common. Maybe that is the right card, but it was unpopular. The next try was:

2(r/w)
Whenever you play a spell that is both red and white cardname is a 5/2 and gains first strike until end of turn.
2/1

We tried tweaking it, and ended up very close to that. If I were working on the set now, I would suggest something a little different. Eventide was in my first year at Wizards of the Coast, so there was a ton to sink in. This card is great for a casual build around that tells you about a cool deck you could build; the red white deck, full of hybrid cards. I like sets having some obvious decks to build. That isn't to say they should be the only decks to build, or the best decks to build. However some straightforward decks that work is a good idea.

However we also need decks that work right in draft. I wasn't thinking about this back then, but our draft format had 2 Shadowmoor packs, and 1 Eventide pack. The Shadowmoor packs do not have any Red/White cards in them at all. The Eventide packs have about 1.4833 per pack. The whole draft opens 8 Eventide packs, for about 11.8667 per draft. Lets say the draft has 12, including one of these. You get half of them, including this one. That means you have 5 other ones in your pool. In a pretty long game, you might draw 17 cards, say this and about 2 of the 5. If this 2 mana creature lives the whole game (and it probably doesn't), you would get 2 triggers, which is pretty cool. However, that is assuming you get a lot of good cards from Eventide; you typically play about 8 cards from each booster set. Here we are assuming that, before you look at what red or white cards you are playing, you are playing 6 of the Red+White cards. That will happen some times, but not frequently.

This card works great in EEE, but doesn't trigger much in SSE drafts. That's fine; some cards work that way. But I think the set has a bit too many cards, especially at common, that work that way. I would consider changing one of the commons. Maybe it would be this one; maybe another. The change could be to make it uncommon, and move a card that works better with Shadowmoor cards down to common. Another approach would be to give you some reward when you play a Red card, and some reward when you play a White card. It would still be great in a RW deck, but would work reasonably well in a deck that is 2/3 Shadowmoor cards.

Maybe after playing with the cards, we would decide to stick with the current version of the Mimic. It is hard to know; that is why we play test. However I would bring up the analysis of why this type of card won't trigger very often. It seems like something design should know, before handing the set off to development.

On other hand that's also a lot of set up, so good for casual, but not for tournaments, especially in the current power level of the game where black decks can turn 3 a dark depths and vampire hexmage into a 20/20 indestructible.

I completely turned that flavor text around. Instead of the spirit protecting a home, it's telling the thief he'll be protected throughout the night, so go rob more houses.

Anyway, this along side of Leyline of Sanctity makes for some fun protection. Too bad attacking doesn't require you to target an opposing player. Both cards fall to cheap removal, but most players i've run across don't run both creature and enchantment removal.

Combine with Ghostly Prison, Norn's Annex, and Peacekeeper.

152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.author: davidhuman
152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.text_parsed: im starting to lower my opinion of this hybrid enchantment cycle.  of course they can be powerful, when given a bunch of multi color creatures to work with, but when you start to have less and less multis, their key strength lapses into flexibility.  now flexibility is nice, but the cards also create an annoying tension where i don't feel like im getting full value unless i put it on a multi color creature.  for me this tension is so strong that i would rather not play the card, and for the most part have not played these cards much.

152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.author: Kenji18
152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.text_parsed:
This card is very useful early, mid, and late game. Turn 3 onto a Naya Hushblade is amazing. +1/+1 and shroud for multicolor, +2/+2 for enchantment, then firebreathing and lifelink. It's a good way to start off a match.
Also, I have topdecked this card many times late game to pull off the win. They don't stack as well as Edge of the Divinity's do, since additional firebreathing is useless, and once the new rules kick in, the additional lifelink won't matter either.
Very good card.

152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.author: Donovan_Fabian
152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.text_parsed:
Basically speaking, shield of the oversoul is the best of the dual color enchantments because it protects the creature its attached to helping to reduce the amount of 2 for 1's against certain decks. The advantage of scourge of the nobilis in particular is in aggro red decks, because that lifelink lets you attack with abandon while not worrying about taking damage reprecussions during your opponents counter. It indeed works well on all sorts of naya creatures, especially the hushblade, but a lot of other ones work just as well. A 7/6 lifelinking thoctar has often made some of my opponents quit. Boros also has tons of red/white (the guilds colors) and in lorwyn there is the aforementioned spitemare, brion stoutarm, and the mimic cycle (I believe the red white one is battle gate mimic), and belligerent hatchling. I still prefer g/w though over red/white.

Oh and yes it does work with naya hushblade, the card doesn't care if the multi color is hybrid as long as its dual colored.

152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.author: Asmodi0000
152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.text_parsed:
A great card. While Shield of the Oversoul is the better enchantment for Naya, I love it because I love R/W and this card often allows me to turn losing situations into either stabilized ones or just straight victories. Double strike and First strike creatures make this card ridiculous, and it's a good way to make use of any stray mana lying around.

Sometimes, I end up slapping this onto a Balefire Liege, just so I can heal an extra 3 whenever I cast a red spell. Casting a Lightning Helix and gaining 9 life is not bad, though I definitely prefer putting Scourges on creatures I'm more inclined to attack with.

152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.author: RJDroid
152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.text_parsed:
I have a Boros Beatdown deck with this in it. Every creature is red and white, so both bonuses apply at all times. Stick this on a Boros Swiftblade or Skyknight Legionnaire for incredible brutality. Or stick it on a Brion Stoutarm before the rules changed for lifelink. Every creature becomes a monster, and I love it.

Sure, you can say that Auras are card disadvantage and that you lose it when the creature dies, but a 3/4 Boros Swiftblade that can pump with extra mana is never going to die in combat, and if your opponent kills it, so what? You gained at least 6 life, and you almost certainly either took a chunk of their life or you took out one of their blockers (If is was a 1/1 chump, you do only gain 3, but that chump didn't block your other guys). You haven't lived until you gain 16 life in a single swing with a Swiftblade, then chuck him with Brion to kill another opponent in a multiplayer match, gaining another 8 life. That cushion of life will go a long way towards winning big multiplayer matches, giving aggressive decks longevity that they otherwise wouldn't have.

You wanna know why this cycle of auras is my favorite EVER?

Transguild Courier {4}

Lifelink, first strike, double strike, trample, indestructible, flying, deathtouch, vigilance, shroud, haste
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, draw a card.

[autocard]Runes of the Deus[/autocard]
[autocard]Shield of the Oversoul[/autocard]
[autocard]Edge of the Divinity[/autocard]
[autocard]Gift of the Deity[/autocard]
[autocard]Favor of the Overbeing[/autocard]
[autocard]Clout of the Dominus[/autocard]
[autocard]Scourge of the Nobilis[/autocard]
You wanna know why this cycle of auras is my favorite EVER?
Let's say we enchant 5-color creature, I don't know, [autocard]Transguild Courier[/autocard], with all of these.
Here's what you get.

[autocard]Transguild Courier[/autocard]         {4}

Lifelink, first strike, double strike, trample, indestructible, flying, deathtouch, vigilance, shroud, haste
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, draw a card.
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to an opponent, that player discards a card.
This creature can't be blocked.
All creatures able to block this creature do so. 
R/W: This creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
                                            24/24

152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.author: r2d2go
152015: Scourge of the Nobilis.text_parsed: It seems pretty decent, but I wouldn't call it any better than that. Firebreathing, even red/white firebreathing, is a nice ability but has little synergy with Lifelink, while Lifelink is also pretty meh in most red/white decks I've seen. Even on a red/white creature, you're only on the upper end of the curve, not smashing it, which isn't great considering that it's hard to reliably get that without building for it.

4/5

152044: Spitemare.author: Asmodi0000
152044: Spitemare.text_parsed:
I accidentally ended up with infinite life.

I had played this guy, and equipped him with the Scourge of the Nobilis. Then, I summoned Deathless Angel. It looks rather obvious now, but the Deathless was a new addition to my deck, and I hadn't seen these two cards together since I only run one copy of each.

In any case, I had the two of them out for two turns before I realized I could make the spitemare indestructible, cast lightning helix on him, and then have him deal 3 damage to himself over and over again (while gaining 3 life each time because of the scourge), until I had a million+ life and I sent 3 damage into my opponent.

I like cards that can do a lot of different things, and this card is just excellent in that regard. While there's "better" 4 CMC R/W cards, I keep playing spitemare because I enjoy being surprised by what he can do.

I had played this guy, and equipped him with the [autocard]Scourge of the Nobilis[/autocard]. Then, I summoned [autocard]Deathless Angel[/autocard]. It looks rather obvious now, but the Deathless was a new addition to my deck, and I hadn't seen these two cards together since I only run one copy of each.

In any case, I had the two of them out for two turns before I realized I could make the spitemare indestructible, cast [autocard]lightning helix[/autocard] on him, and then have him deal 3 damage to himself over and over again (while gaining 3 life each time because of the scourge), until I had a million+ life and I sent 3 damage into my opponent.

I like cards that can do a lot of different things, and this card is just excellent in that regard. While there's "better" 4 CMC R/W cards, I keep playing spitemare because I enjoy being surprised by what he can do.

That's indeed a great combo card with a still somewhat resistant 1/3 body, and being able to double any counters including loyality counters from planeswalkers, time or fade counters from vanish / fade permanents, or tower counters from Helix Pinnacle, storage counters on lands or whatever you've got a great assortment of combos besides the common +1/+1 or charge counters.
The downside is that you'll regrettably have to find another card to tap this guy with, since attacking with it won't be a good idea...
Also, i'd have loved this guy if he was able to remove the counters instead. Would still not made him broken since this is a Johnny card that requires comboing to do anything, but apart from that this guy is still quite useful.

152046: Gilder Bairn.author: sarroth
152046: Gilder Bairn.text_parsed:
I'm with Swordfishtrombones on using this card with planeswalkers and levelers, but I'm unclear how it works with Magosi, The Waterveil - Pay U and tap Magosi to get an eon counter and you skip your next turn. At some point you use Gilder Bairn to put two eon counters on Magosi. You can then tap Magosi and remove a counter to take an extra turn; however Gilder Bairn's adding of counters doesn't let you utilize the extra counters because Magosi is returned to your hand as a part of its effect, so the extra counters disappears.

Gilder Bairn is certainly versatile, though. Great for levelers, as already mentioned, in any multicolor decks to get Kargan Dragonlords, Transcendent Masters, or, as Swordfishtrombones mentioned, Lighthouse Chronologists.

He also dominates with Mycoloth for a ton of Saproling tokens and the Myojins (especially Cleansing Fire) of the Kamigawa block to be able to use their divinity counters twice, or repeatedly if you give Gilder Bairn indestructibility or regenerate.

152046: Gilder Bairn.author: Diachronos
152046: Gilder Bairn.text_parsed:
With the Rise of the Eldrazi set out, you can essentially do his ability an infinite number of times if you have a Training Grounds out and Paradise Mantle on him. Tap him for {(G/U)}, use it to untap him, and keep doing it until you're satisfied.

I can see him being extremely useful for Planeswalker users. All but four of them (Ajani Vengeant, Nissa Revane, and both versions of Jace, but their abilities are so good that it's worth having to wait a bit longer) would be able to use their best ability on the turn they were dropped, and that's if you only used one!

152046: Gilder Bairn.text_parsed:
I'd untap that!

This guy has synergy with the two most over-linked cards ever: Doubling Season and Training Grounds.

I use all three in my Simic deck, along with Graft creatures and Evolution Vat.
The Vat can be used to add counters to any creature you want them on,
or to tap Bairn if you have no better way.

Psionic Gift is also hilarious on him, especially if Training Grounds is out-
One G or U to ping for one and double the counters on something,
as many times as you care to pay for it.

And while he may not be my favorite foil ever (that's Hallowed Fountain),
he is certainly one of the best.

152046: Gilder Bairn.author: aaron987
152046: Gilder Bairn.text_parsed:
This would work well with Shape of the wiitigo. Just put it right on this guy. He would immediately turn into a 7/9. Then each turn you attack with him. Next turn, he gets another +1/+1 for attacking, and after attacking, pay to untap him and double it for the next turn.

If the turn when you play the wiitigo is called turn 1, it would look like this:

Turn 1: Shape of the wiitigo makes him 7/9. Attack.
Turn 2: +1/+1 for attacking makes him 13/15. Untap. Attack. Play his ability to double it and make it 26/30.
Turn 3: +1/+1 for attacking makes him 27/31. Untap. Attack. Ability again to make him 54/62.
Rinse and repeat if they are still alive.

For more fun, find a way to give him trample.

152046: Gilder Bairn.author: Lord_of_Gelectrodes
152046: Gilder Bairn.text_parsed:
Here's this little guy's backstory.
Plane: Lorwyn/Shadowmoor
The plan moves along perfectly. The few meddling slugs that have gotten in my way were quickly disposed of by my minion, Kraj. All of the multiverse now moves to my whim, for the planeswalkers are but pawns in my master plan. They think I am the weak servant. My froggy suit fooled them easily. As the Darksteel Reactor counts down, Even those who were my greatest foes cannot stop me now. Today I take over this pathetic little plane, tomorrow, the entire multiverse!!

Don't underestimate an Ouphe in a frog suit.
