157202: Unwilling Recruit.author: Donovan_Fabian
157202: Unwilling Recruit.text_parsed:
Ah I don't think comparing it to threaten/act of treason is a fair example. Lets say your opponent has a 3/3 drake or something, basically anything 3/3 with flying, and you got 6 mana. Not to unreasonable, and unless the game is vs. aggro and is decided quickly, you are likely to have that much during a game. If your opponent has no other flying creatures, you could snatch their creature, and hit them with it for 6 without being blocked. Also works the same way if your opponent has just attacked with everything guessing you can't counter attack and then play this on one of their big creatures.

The best thing about it is that x can be 0, you don't have to increase its attack power if you don't want to, but it still gives you the option of doing so late game when you don't have the mana. Grab the reigns is arguably better, but then mirrodin is about to rotate out of extended.

157285: Crag Puca.author: HairlessThoctar
157285: Crag Puca.text_parsed:
@Thrallmighty

Before Magic 2010, combat damage used the stack just like spells and abilities.
Basically the damage that was applied during the combat step could be responded to.

So basically you could block with this guy and switch his p/t making him a 4/2.
It would apply 4 damage to the blocked creature.
Then in response to the damage being applied, switch it back to a 2/4.

In essence, this card was a three mana 4/4.
Which is pretty darn good any way you cut it.
These days, it's much more underwhelming.

Ce la vie...

157286: Noggle Bandit.author: SavageBrain89
157286: Noggle Bandit.text_parsed:
The art work is bad, really bad. I agree, its too big and cartoony for a race of half human/half horse people. The noggles should have been drawn with a much taller, slender, lean build; with darker skin and background to make them look more fearsome. Almost all the art work for them is juvenile and negates any serious attitude of thier race; a race that should have been really evil and cunning.

As for the card and its mechanics, they're ok. The bandit isn't really all that, great despite being almost inblockable, because its susceptible to just about every type of removal that exists. The only good solution to this problem would be to play Clout of the Dominus on the bandit, that way it would be a 4/4, almost unblockable, shrouded powerhouse.

157288: Deathbringer Liege.author: medomai
157288: Deathbringer Liege.text_parsed:
To answer your question Gezus82.

Debtors knell's ability is on the stack, not the creature your trying to resurect. According to the following from the MTG comprensive rule book, a spell is defined as:

111.1. A spell is a card on the stack. As the first step of being cast (see rule 601, “Casting Spells”), the card becomes a spell and is moved to the top of the stack from the zone it was in, which is usually its owner’s hand. (See rule 405, “Stack.”) A spell remains on the stack as a spell until it resolves (see rule 608, “Resolving Spells and Abilities”), is countered (see rule 701.5), or otherwise leaves the stack. For more information, see section 6, “Spells, Abilities, and Effects.”

Ergo, debtors knell won't help you use Deathbringer Liege's "whenever you play a spell" abilitys. Which really sucks for me since I use White black reserection. I recomend bouncing your cheap creatures in play or graveyard to get the effect your after. Good luck.

157288: Deathbringer Liege.author: billpasdmf
157288: Deathbringer Liege.text_parsed:
I got into a bit of a debate w/ some friends over this card.

One side contending that the tap/destroy abilities were triggered effects and can be used to tap/destroy creatures that have protection from black/white.(similar to the ruling on Journey to Nowhere) The wording on the card reading "you" may tap/destroy target creature, as opposed to the Liege directly targeting it by itself.

The other side of course insisting that the Liege is the one doing the targeting and that, of course it couldn't destroy anything w/ protection from either of it's colors. i.e. Black Knight or White Knight

Any thoughts?

157288: Deathbringer Liege.author: gelleetin
157288: Deathbringer Liege.text_parsed:
@billpasdmf

According to the comprehensive rules:

"The source of a triggered ability (other than a delayed triggered ability) on the stack, or one that has triggered and is waiting to be put on the stack, is the object whose ability triggered." (112.7)

"A permanent or player with protection can't be targeted by spells with the stated quality and can't be targeted by abilities from a source with the stated quality." (702.14b)

So, the source of the triggered abilities is Deathbringer Liege, and creature with pro-black/pro-white cannot be targeted by those abilities because the Liege fits the stated quality (black/white).

I am guessing the confusion stems from Journey's Interaction with Emrakul, which has protection from colored spells- Journey's only works because it is a triggered ability, not a spell. The ability would still have a white source.
157288: Deathbringer Liege.text_posted:
@billpasdmf

According to the comprehensive rules:

"The source of a triggered ability (other than a delayed triggered ability) on the stack, or one that has triggered and is waiting to be put on the stack, is the [b]object whose ability triggered[/b]." (112.7)

"A permanent or player with protection can't be targeted by spells with the stated quality and can't be targeted by abilities from [b]a source with the stated quality[/b]." (702.14b)

So, the source of the triggered abilities is [autocard]Deathbringer Liege[/autocard], and creature with pro-black/pro-white cannot be targeted by those abilities because the Liege fits the stated quality (black/white).

I am guessing the confusion stems from Journey's Interaction with Emrakul, which has protection from colored [b]spells[/b]- Journey's only works because it is a triggered [b]ability[/b], not a spell.  The ability would still have a white source.

157288: Deathbringer Liege.author: DaMaster012
157288: Deathbringer Liege.text_parsed:
Dear God, WHAT were they thinking when they printed this?

Creature advantage is often key in Magic, and this guy just gives it to you WAY too easily. Aside from the obvious that he gives you free removal for even the smallest of spells and that every kill spell grants you an extra kill spell, he also buffs your creatures at the same time, making all your s#!t with lifelink even harder for you opponent to deal with as you gain life to the point where they couldn't possibly kill you.

Why does it have to be "destroy target tapped creature?" Why couldn't it be something like "When you play a black spell, you may have target tapped creature not untap during its controllers unstap step" or "When you play a black spell, you may have target opponent lose 1 life for each tapped creature he or she controls." Yeah, the first suggestion is more up blues' alley than blacks', but the second would still be powerful without being game-breaking, and with his 'white spell' ability you could still go to town on your opponent with Assassinates, and Royal Assassin would've have a field-day with this guy. But no, they gave Deathbringer Liege the ability to kill on his lonesome. (And Royal Assassin went on to become best friends with Sleep, anyway.)

One thing I haven't seen brought up yet is how you can have more than one of these out at once; my younger brother once got all three out while he was playing his Orzhov deck, played a Mortify, and cleared his opponents' field. Another thing I haven't seen mentioned is that has so much recursion that even if you do kill this guy, he probably won't stay dead for long. And you can't slap something like Oblivion Ring or Arrest on this guy, because has access to Mortify or any other run-of-the-mil white enchantment destruction. The only way to really get rid of this guy is to remove it from the game with something like Path to Exile or kill it when you've got a Leyline of the Void out.

Seriously, this guy can even kill Emrakul; think about that.

5 out of 5; few creatures can earn my hate like this thing has.

157394: Hallowed Burial.author: The_Trendkill
157394: Hallowed Burial.text_parsed:
I would often much rather have this card than Day of Judgment or Wrath of God, simply because it can deal with creatures that the two aforementioned can't, such as those that are indestructible or have persist. More notably, it gets around graveyard hax and cards that would otherwise prevent creatures from being destroyed, which are both annoyingly common in multiplayer.

As an added note, this card is a massive curveball in EDH/Commander, because you can use it to put commanders on the bottom of their owner's library, which is one of the few places from which you cannot opt to return your commander to the command zone. Playing it can make you either a hero or a huge jerk.

157394: Hallowed Burial.author: JaxsonBateman
157394: Hallowed Burial.text_parsed:
Love this card - I play in a meta with a lot of Wraths, DoJs and Damnations, so when players build creature decks they know to protect said creatures with Eldrazi Monument or some kind of recursion like Genesis.

So we were getting along fine with that arrangement... and then Hallowed Burial showed up, and started making a real mess of things. I personally prefer it over Final Judgment - Final Judgment has the much better effect IMO, but of course Hallowed Burial is a lot more accessible at 5 mana which is why I prefer it.
Often waiting until 6 for a sweeper can be a deadly if you don't have board supremacy (which is unlikely if you want said sweeper ^^).

157395: Talara's Battalion.author: Mode
157395: Talara's Battalion.text_parsed:
Man, this is one easy-to-cast cheap fatty in the right deck.

Use it on turn two with green spells with an alternate cost like Manamorphose, Vine Dryad or Skyshroud Cutter.
Use it on turn three with just about any green one-drop, Firewild Borderpost.

Oh, and then there's also Green Sun's Zenith, where you don't have to worry about any other green spells at all.

Could be fun on turn one as well: Cast Skyshroud Cutter and sacrifice it for Metamorphosis, then you can cast Talara's Battalion and something else for up to 3 mana.
(Or you could even just cast a WUBRG creature, although i can barely imagine any of these suiting into a monogreen deck for this narrow combo...maybe Bringer of the Green Dawn)

157399: Umbra Stalker.author: DarthParallax
157399: Umbra Stalker.text_parsed:
Lord of the Pit starts the conversation about Black Chroma/Devotion. Demons are an EXCELLENT resource to mine for Black Mana Symbols, but I also wouldn't want to use too many of them. Very few are truly worth it, but at the same time, a high percentage of 'Black Mana Symbol Creatures' that are worth it, are demons. Reiver Demon seems like an outstanding choice, but Griselbrand feels pretty hardcore and possibly more heat than you want to pack, depending on your format, metagame, #ofplayers, and the hate you could expect to be boarded in against you either next game or next week.

Buried Alive is clearly far more important than Entomb in this deck's instance, because the most # Black Symbols Entomb can net is either 3 or 4, but Buried Alive can get 6 without hardly trying.

Knights are also a great option. There aren't an overwhelmingly huge # of black Knights, but there are enough to give you a choice of options from.

Finally, while it's certainly tempting to look at Shadowmoor and Eventide and cram everything bigger than Phyrexian Obliterator in, I think the key to the deck being awesome is being VERY deliberate and SPECIFIC in your selection of the 5-mana Symbol slot:

Don't use more than 1 or 2 of these:

Demigod of Revenge: Works best in highly Aggressive decks, also since you'll be running Buried Alive, running 4 copies is a smart option and you can include any of many single-reanimation cards to get all of them out of your grave. Excellent Plan B for when your Umbra Stalker runs smack dab into Wrath of God, and if you can find an Instant Reanimation effect, probably the ONLY good strategy to escape a simple Relic of Progenitus ruining your whole game plan.

Ghastlord of Fugue: Simply put, not a Spike option for your deck. It's got some good elements for Control and Disruption, but I'd include it as a wild card to something unexpected instead of trying to have this be an additional axis of the deck after Umbra Stalker.

Divinity of Pride: A Boss Ass ***. The Lifelink is incredibly badass. Good for Aggression or Midrange, and I'd probably either 1x or 2x it in every build, next to just one other 5-cost from Eventide.

Deity of Scars: Highly unrecommended without Gift of the Deity, highly recommended with it. Not a lot else to say. More dependent on its "themed Enchantment" than the other Avatar-Gods of Eventide. Helm of the Ghastlord is also helpful for the Blue one.


Recommended Build:
22 Lands
4x Nykthos, Shrine to Nyx
4x Godless Shrine
4x Marsh Flats
10x Swamp
22 creatures
4x Umbra Stalker
4x Demigod of Revenge
2x Divinity of Pride
3x Black Knight
3x Stillmoon Cavalier
1x Rakdos the Defiler
1x Obzedat, Ghost Council
4x Reiver Demon
16 spells
4x Buried Alive
4x Reanimate
4x Dark Ritual
4x Sign in Blood

There's no room for Phyrexian Obliterator in this version, and if I'd wanted to go for Broken, I wouldn't have considered anything until first scratching down '4x Necropotence, 4x Griselbrand' I like combining Reanimate with Lifegaining effects, because it's a pretty confident promise of a powerful graveyard combo, but it does give your opponents opportunity to try to punish you for paying too much life before you're ready. Also a good reason to include Fetch-Shock land suite. If this deck is a bit too powerful or fast for your play group, pick a second color after Black and put in a mono colored card that gives you a big huge effect-- like Comet Storm for Red or Avacyn, Angel of Hope for White. Nykthos + Fetch + Shock is boss at getting the mana you need for a heavy-weighted card in an off-color.
157399: Umbra Stalker.text_posted:
[autocard]Lord of the Pit[/autocard] starts the conversation about Black Chroma/Devotion. Demons are an EXCELLENT resource to mine for Black Mana Symbols, but I also wouldn't want to use too many of them. Very few are truly worth it, but at the same time, a high percentage of 'Black Mana Symbol Creatures' that are worth it, are demons. [autocard]Reiver Demon[/autocard] seems like an outstanding choice, but [autocard]Griselbrand[/autocard] feels pretty hardcore and possibly more heat than you want to pack, depending on your format, metagame, #ofplayers, and the hate you could expect to be boarded in against you either next game or next week. 

[autocard]Buried Alive[/autocard] is clearly far more important than [autocard]Entomb[/autocard] in this deck's instance, because the most # Black Symbols Entomb can net is either 3 or 4, but Buried Alive can get 6 without hardly trying. 

Knights are also a great option. There aren't an overwhelmingly huge # of black Knights, but there are enough to give you a choice of options from. 

Finally, while it's certainly tempting to look at [i]Shadowmoor[/i] and [i]Eventide[/i] and cram everything bigger than [autocard]Phyrexian[/autocard] Obliterator in, I think the key to the deck being awesome is being VERY deliberate and SPECIFIC in your selection of the 5-mana Symbol slot: 

Don't use more than 1 or 2 of these: 

[autocard]Demigod of Revenge[/autocard]: Works best in highly Aggressive decks, also since you'll be running Buried Alive, running 4 copies is a smart option and you can include any of many single-reanimation cards to get all of them out of your grave. Excellent Plan B for when your Umbra Stalker runs smack dab into Wrath of God, and if you can find an Instant Reanimation effect, probably the ONLY good strategy to escape a simple [autocard]Relic of Progenitus[/autocard] ruining your whole game plan.

[autocard]Ghastlord of Fugue[/autocard]: Simply put, not a Spike option for your deck. It's got some good elements for Control and Disruption, but I'd include it as a wild card to something unexpected instead of trying to have this be an additional axis of the deck after Umbra Stalker. 

[autocard]Divinity of Pride[/autocard]: A Boss Ass Bitch. The Lifelink is incredibly badass. Good for Aggression or Midrange, and I'd probably either 1x or 2x it in every build, next to just one other 5-cost from Eventide.

[autocard]Deity of Scars[/autocard]: Highly unrecommended without [autocard]Gift of the Deity[/autocard], highly recommended with it. Not a lot else to say. More dependent on its "themed Enchantment" than the other Avatar-Gods of Eventide. [autocard]Helm of the Ghastlord[/autocard] is also helpful for the Blue one.

4x [autocard]Godless Shrine[/autocard]
4x [autocard]Marsh Flats[/autocard]

16 spells

4x [autocard]Reanimate[/autocard]
4x [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard]
4x [autocard]Sign in Blood[/autocard]

There's no room for Phyrexian Obliterator in this version, and if I'd wanted to go for Broken, I wouldn't have considered anything until first scratching down '4x [autocard]Necropotence[/autocard], 4x [autocard]Griselbrand[/autocard]' I like combining Reanimate with Lifegaining effects, because it's a pretty confident promise of a powerful graveyard combo, but it does give your opponents opportunity to try to punish you for paying too much life before you're ready. Also a good reason to include Fetch-Shock land suite. If this deck is a bit too powerful or fast for your play group, pick a second color after Black and put in a mono colored card that gives you a big huge effect-- like [autocard]Comet Storm[/autocard] for Red or [autocard]Avacyn, Angel of Hope[/autocard] for White. 157399: Umbra Stalker.author: blurrymadness
157399: Umbra Stalker.text_parsed:
Devotion is the reincarnation of Chroma and Grey Merchant is the reincarnation of this card (oddly enough.) I feel that they've done a very good job evolving this into something that not only feels more black but is actually usable, both in casual and competitive circles.

This guy was a sad attempt thrown together I'm afraid. Where Sanity Grinding is innovative and worth a "build around me" deck (you can easily mill 20-40 cards with it) this guy is merely comparable with Mortivore (especially in multiplayer; where you'll get the time to reach 7 mana.) He's not interesting in reanimator or ramp (you need a lot in your grave, there are better targets), he's not that fun (he's just fat) and other cards use his weakness (grave hate) and his benefit (getting absurdly huge) much better; such as Consuming Aberration; and again, are much more fun for "build around" IMO.

I hope they do another attempt with Chroma (rather than only replace it with devotion.) Even if this guy had evasion I feel like he'd just be a boring fatty; a change in the ability to something like "When ~ etb, exile all cards from all graveyards. For each black mana symbol on the exiled cards other creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn and ~ gets a +1/+1 counter"; now he's a Dread Cacodemon who exiles graveyards, has a drawback, and is decidedly neat to build around (as he wants you to use your graveyard, but then kills it!)

157401: Snakeform.author: Ladnarud
157401: Snakeform.text_parsed:
This is actually an exceedingly good card, even when compared to cards like Sudden Spoiling and Ovinize. Each of these 3 cards have their own pros and cons compared to each other.

Sudden Spoiling
Pros:
—turns ALL creatures a target player controls
—split second, blocking out response spells
Cons:
—turns creatures into 2 toughness, which can be annoying if you can only ping them for 1 damage and not kill them (assuming that's what you want to do in the first place)

Snakeform
Pros:
—turns the creature GREEN until end of turn, which can take away many restrictions and open up possibilities (including 'non-color' restrictions)
—you get to draw a card as an instant as well
Cons:
—gives the creature 1 power, which can still do damage (even as low as it may be)
—it's very costly for a spell with only 1 target

Ovinize
Pros:
—lower mana cost than others
—turns a creature into the weakest possible creature, at 0/1, which is absolutely no threat in any way on its own and can be very easily disposed of
Cons:
—it has no extra effects and only targets 1 creature

Anyway... I'm also under the impression that a card that has a split cost such as this will satisfy any color requirement involving either possible costs. Put simply 2G/U is strictly better than 1UG

157403: Moonhold.author: DoctorKenneth
157403: Moonhold.text_parsed:
Qazior: This is pre-M10, when the wording was changed back to "cast" to avoid confusing issues with putting things into play (like with Elvish Piper) and casting things from your hand. Apparently people had difficulty undersanding that Phage the Untouchable can only be played from your hand. With her mana cost. Period.

Also, Silence or Orim's Chant are usually preferable to this, if that's the direction you're going. I mean, they don't stop lands, so this is somewhat superior in the early game to get the advantage in tempo. But you'd get more advantage on turn three with a three-drop creature or via removal than using all your mana on a delaying tactic like this. In that case, you're just using your third turn play to deny them a third turn play, and coming out slightly ahead. The one-mana spells do a good deal of disruption on their own, earlier (where it matters most) and cheaper (so you have some mana open early to keep up with plays yourself). Generally, in modern control, you want to focus on creatures anyway. There's not much good modern land destruction, as of yet, so it's much easier and more efficient to disrupt their spell play. So go for Silence, and you'll usually be buying yourself a turn all the same, and at a lower price.

157405: Wake Thrasher.author: HairlessThoctar
157405: Wake Thrasher.text_parsed:
For any newer players here, this card used to be crap.

Once upon a time, Magic had a thing called "Mana Burn" that basically said that any unused mana you had at the end of your turn did damage to you.
Which meant that tapping out each turn to make this guy huge next turn would do a lot of damage to you over the course of the game.

Then they got rid of mana burn and this guy became awesome.

157405: Wake Thrasher.author: alphagprime
157405: Wake Thrasher.text_parsed:
Merrow Commerce
Wanderwine Prophets
Lullmage Mentor
Stonybrook Schoolmaster
Summon the School
Merfolk Reejerey

This combo allows you to make an absurd amount of Merfolk tokens, tap them to counter spell which makes more tokens, that you can use to make more tokens, all the while building an absurd amount of things to untap and plenty of fodder to sac to Wanderwine Prophets so that you never let the welling go down on Wake Thrasher.

Throw in Judge of Currents to get extra mileage out of your tapping and Sigil Tracer to double the output of Summon the School (which makes just enough tokens to tap them all to get Summon the School back out of the yard).

Holy crap...that looks like a deck =)

This combo allows you to make an absurd amount of Merfolk tokens, tap them to counter spell which makes more tokens, that you can use to make more tokens, all the while building an absurd amount of things to untap and plenty of fodder to sac to Wanderwine Prophets so that you never let the welling go down on Wake Thrasher.

Throw in [autocard]Judge of Currents[/autocard] to get extra mileage out of your tapping and [autocard]Sigil Tracer[/autocard] to double the output of Summon the School (which makes just enough tokens to tap them all to get Summon the School back out of the yard).

Holy crap...that looks like a deck =)

157406: Creakwood Liege.author: JU4
157406: Creakwood Liege.text_parsed: I recently played a match with my mono-blue Shenanigans deck versus my opponent's b/g beatdown deck. I had managed to keep his creatures tapped down with a few Narcolepsys and a Freed From the Real. He played a Creakwood Liege, which I cast Control Magic on. He Played a Rendclaw Trow, I Cloned the Liege. He plays his second Creakwood Liege, which I once again Control Magic'd. At this point I've got three 6/6 Lieges, and three 7/7 Wurm Tokens as well as the ability to produce three more of said Tokens during each of my upkeeps. It was a glorious example of what I built that Shenanigans deck to do. It doesn't have a lot going in the way of win conditions, but lots of control, card draw and flexibility. That game also very much impressed me with the power of this, the Creakwood Liege. I wouldn't have had any semblance of a chance if I hadn't managed to steal them away.

157406: Creakwood Liege.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
157406: Creakwood Liege.text_parsed:
Guest1467942152 wrote:
"His ability gets exponentially better the more you got."

I'm sorry, but you are incorrect.

1 in play: 3 power on the table every turn.
2 in play: 10 power (2 Tokens each getting +4/+4) on the table every turn.
3 in play: 21 power (3 Tokens each getting +6/+6) on the table every turn.
4 in play: 36 power (4 Tokens each getting +8/+8) on the table every turn.

The equation producing this is 2x²+x, and therefore, he only gets geometrically better the more you got. :P

Also, while already needing a load of mana and colors, a kicked Rite of Replication on him is really lulzy!

157411: Thunderblust.author: DarthParallax
157411: Thunderblust.text_parsed:
I like it. It improves on Ball Lightning's original Design, by making it a lot higher CMC, meaning it's not quite so terrifying to race (2 turns is a lot in Red), but with the added benefit of dealing roughly double damage, which is to say that Timmy cards are more fun than Spike cards USUALLY.

Inferno Titan might be a little better, but when you are thinking of making a Red 'mana=damage' deck, and going for elemental creatures that sacrifice themselves and stuff to cram as much fire-and-lightning based artwork as possible, Thunderblust still very nice.


If you have Premium Deck Series: Fire & Lightning, I would suggest substituting Hammer of Bogardan with this as they have close CMC's and similar 'return' effects.

157414: Nightmare Incursion.author: scumbling1
157414: Nightmare Incursion.text_parsed:
"How and why is this rated so low? Cranial Extraction and Extirpate are freaking bombs in duo color or mono color black decks."

It probably has to do with having a huge CMC on a card that doesn't effect the game state immediately. Extirpate and Cranial Extraction were bombs against combo decks (and really only sideboarded ones, at that) because they could be used before the opponent could put together his combo. Six turns is a lot of time to wait, and you can't just rush out this card with a Dark Ritual without hurting it's potency.

Extirpate and Cranial Extraction also had the decency to hit any copies of the exiled cards that might be in the opponent's hand, generating at least card parity. Nightmare Incursion is card disadvantage every time you cast it.
157414: Nightmare Incursion.text_posted:

157415: Beckon Apparition.author: DeathDark
157415: Beckon Apparition.text_parsed:
Not sure what AlphaNumerical was thinking. This card has nice combos within its own set with Deathbringer Liege and Voracious Hatchling. With the liege, you kill something, exile a card from a graveyard, and get a 1/1 with flying for 1. The much less effective combo with the hatchling just removes 2 of the counters, which is quite useful, if you didn't know.

Also, those who recall Teysa, Orzhov Scion, this can be used to fuel her first ability. With three of these and her alone, you exile 3 cards from a graveyard, and exile one from the battlefield. Albeit it you won't have 3 at once, just having that slight extra boost would always be nice.

157420: Crackleburr.author: Internet_decks_lame
157420: Crackleburr.text_parsed:
Not very easy to get going, although I see this card only improving with future blocks once more red & blue hybrids are printed. Combines well with Crag Puca being another hybrid (with 4 toughness) which has a little better staying power then most cheaper R/U hybrid creature choices. And once your able to crack some burrs a little, just send Crag to lay down the beats with its switch effect.

Also combos well with Razorfin hunter. Just tapping down a couple of Razors to deal 2 points anywhere... then attack with Crackle using the untap bounce effect before blockers are declared (potentially removing another blocker if the first 2 points hasn't already done so) and then adding 2 more points from the Razors if needed, before any blockers are even declared! Now add a messier field with tons of mana... clear the board on one combat step without combat damage? Hmmm.... Don't forget this little baby is an elemental... tutor anyone? Flamekin Harbinger, Hmmmm....

5/5 (only gonna get better when more R/U hybrids get printed)

157420: Crackleburr.author: Mode
157420: Crackleburr.text_parsed:
To get your blue creatures tapped, here are some ideas:
-Sky Hussar: free card draw in your upkeep. Possibly one of the best combos in general.
-Blue conspire spells (for twice the fun):
Æthertow to uber-bounce two attackers (or blockers),
Ghastly Discovery to draw four and discard two.
Memory Sluice to mill for eight (the cheapest choice at 1cc, bot necessarily that useful...maybe if that gets your Threshold.)

Especially useful are also effects that ask you to tap an untapped creature for actvation, since this immediately let's you reuse the effect once your blue creatures got untapped with Crackleburr.
-Opposition: good control card.
-Tradewind Rider: two boomerangs each turn doesn't sound bad.
-'tapping lords': Grand Architect (insane mana ramp for artifacts),
Azami, Lady of Scrolls (huge card advantage) or
Patron Wizard (for soft-counter control).
-Benthicore is somewhat useful since it gives you two blue creatures that it can also tap (and gets untapped and shroud that way), and is an Elemental as well.

-Cryptic Gateway works nice in tribal decks:
Tap two creatures for the gateway, put another creature on the field.
Untap them with Crackleburr, bounce a creature.
Tap these two again for the gateway, put a further creature on the field.
Now you can tap the two new ones again for the gateway, and untap them again with Crackleburr if you can afford the mana. You see where this is going, especially when combined with Azami for instance.
(Pity Smokebraider ain't blue :P You could always add a Quicksilver Elemental, though...
Wind Zendikon also works great with Crackleburr, if you have two of them, that means unlimited Unsummons for you.)

157420: Crackleburr.author: blurrymadness
157420: Crackleburr.text_parsed:
VERY elegant. With aforementioned in-block combo:
T1: Stream Hopper
T2: Riverfall Mimic , attack for 1
T3: This , attack for 4
T4: Use this ability! , attack for 5, 3 to the face

Total of 13 damage by T4. Not bad..

Notice that the ability:
-needs two red blue, which you'll have without removal.
-needs 4 mana and a tap, which you'll have the turn after this guy comes into play (ideal play of course..)
-requires 7 cards to do! A perfect opening hand means that this combo works if uninterrupted, and it doesn't matter what you draw.

Now, there are better ways to use him of course. T3 mimic with Clout will do the 6 on t3 and is harder to interrupt. T4 you drop this guy, attack for 6, T5 do your combo for an extra 3, attack for 8.

1+6+6+8+3 = 24 damage and a bounce. Again.. neat card.

157971: Leering Emblem.author: Kenji18
157971: Leering Emblem.text_parsed:
This card reminds me of my old UG Herd Gnarr deck I used to have. It worked by attacking with a Herd Gnarr that was pumped by repeatedly playing Shrieking Drake. This card is way better, though, because you can equip it to a creature that already has trample or other useful evasion, then sink U into the drake to pump it. I guess Leering Emblem was designed with cascade in mind, though.

Perhaps something like Gloryscale Viashino with Leering Emblem attacks after a Violent Outburst cascades into a Colossal Might. It looks like you are attacking with a 3/3 creature, but then hit them with the combat trick to turn him into a 18/15 trampler. Pray for no removal though.

157972: Ward of Bones.author: mutantman
157972: Ward of Bones.text_parsed:
I've tried this card in multiplayer and it just doesn't do enough. Sure, it's occasionally good against certain decks, like rampy ones that play lots of lands, but most of the time it's just ineffective. It costs six mana and it can never really lock them out of anything. If you have no creatures, they can just cast their first creature and beat down on your empty board.

I've just never really been happy to draw it. Maybe if you really built around it, you could do something, but at that point you're building your deck for the purpose of stopping anyone from playing anything, which seems...not much fun.

157972: Ward of Bones.author: Ferlord
157972: Ward of Bones.text_parsed:
This card played in multiplayer (EDH, casual, etc.) is one of "those" cards.

You know, "those" ones that make everyone cringe, like Sorin Markov and any of those old banned white cards (Limited Resources, Land Tax, and Balance). Thus is why these cards (minus Sorin) are banned.

I'm surprised this hasn't become banned considering it's terrible way of making a slow game like EDH even slower. Another underrated card that is one of "those" cards is Oppression. It slows play down to such a halt and can be played on turn one (Dark Ritual and this isn't too uncommon) that it makes you one of "those" players who you don't want to play against.

Another one is Contamination: another 3-cost black enchantment. Instead of just slowing play, you could entirely cancel out an opponent with a simple combo using it and Sheoldred, Whispering One.

So, please don't include this (or any of the above) in your EDH deck. You'll do your friends a great favour.
157972: Ward of Bones.text_posted:
This card played in multiplayer (EDH, casual, etc.) is one of "those" cards. 

You know, "those" ones that make everyone cringe, like [autocard]Sorin Markov[/autocard] and any of those old banned white cards ([autocard]Limited Resources[/autocard], [autocard]Land Tax[/autocard], and [autocard]Balance[/autocard]). Thus is why these cards (minus Sorin) are banned. 

I'm surprised this hasn't become banned considering it's terrible way of making a slow game like EDH even slower. Another underrated card that is one of "those" cards is [autocard]Oppression[/autocard]. It slows play down to such a halt and can be played on turn one ([autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard] and this isn't too uncommon) that it makes you one of "those" players who you don't want to play against.

Another one is [autocard]Contamination[/autocard]: another 3-cost black enchantment. Instead of just slowing play, you could entirely cancel out an opponent with a simple combo using it and [autocard]Sheoldred, Whispering One[/autocard]. 

So, please don't include this (or any of the above) in your EDH deck. You'll do your friends a great favour.

A turn or two later got a vorinclex, which allowed me to do a massive genesis wave. I love it when rulings are written in a way that reminds you that there's not some rules robot out there making them, but an actual person. In this situation, it's like "Ok, so I know some of you out there have trouble reading, so let me spell it out for you as if you were a child *sigh*"

As for the card itself.... as an aggro player who often plays blitz or token decks, and as someone who gets bored with stalled out EDH matches taking forever, I hate this card with a burning passion.... but as someone who wants to grow and expand as a player, I know I'm going to need to pick one up sometime for future control/lockdown decks. If you can't beat 'em....

157972: Ward of Bones.author: IceMetalPunk
157972: Ward of Bones.text_parsed:
I remember playing a game of Commander once where my friend used this in conjunction with Worldslayer. So first he put the Worldslayer on something. Next turn, he floated 6 mana, hit someone with the Worldslayer-equipped creature, then used his floating mana to drop a Ward of Bones.

For those not already facepalming, this was the result: everything was gone except Worldslayer and Ward of Bones, so everyone could only play 1 land, 3 artifacts, 1 creature, and 1 enchantment. No more. He refused to play anything to give us more stuff...it was insanity. I don't remember how that game ended, but I wouldn't be surprised if we all just rage-quit.

157972: Ward of Bones.author: jonrds
157972: Ward of Bones.text_parsed:
@daerien

Arent all suspended creatures cast at the same time? The last counters are removed at the same time, so you cast all the creatures before any enter the battlefield, allowing you to get around this the same way you do with flash.
157972: Ward of Bones.text_posted:
@daerien

Arent all suspended creatures cast at the same time? The last counters are removed at the same time, so you cast all the creatures before any enter the battlefield, allowing you to get around this the same way you do with flash.

157972: Ward of Bones.author: PolskiSuzeren
157972: Ward of Bones.text_parsed: No, jonrds, all suspended cards are not cast at the same time. You have to pull counters off individually, and once the last counter is pulled off of something with suspend, the trigger to cast it is immediately put on the stack, then the spell has to resolve. After all of that, the next trigger to pull a counter off can be resolved, and if you now have too many creatures for the Ward, you won't be able to cast the spell, and it will remain in exile.
157972: Ward of Bones.text_posted: No, jonrds, all suspended cards are not cast at the same time. 157973: Sapling of Colfenor.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
157973: Sapling of Colfenor.text_parsed:
The people who finalize the wording are very considerate with this card. If it had read, "You lose life, then gain life" it would have had the same effect, but some players would think revealing a 5/5 at five life would result in death. (It wouldn't- state-based effects like losing from zero or less life are checked only after the ability resolution is complete.)

Magic: the Gathering is extremely complex, but it's designed so that you can usually play it well enough without knowing all the rules.

157975: Endless Horizons.author: Mobenator
157975: Endless Horizons.text_parsed:
Great card if your playing a multicolour deck with the dual lands from Ravnica block. It allows you to remove cards like Hallowed Fountain and Sacred Foundry because they have the Plains subtype so can help with mana issues if your not running green for fixing.

It also provides a means to thin your deck of those not so useful lands you don't want to draw late game, as long as you have 2-3 sources of white mana you can probably remove all the plains from your deck as long as your playing other basic lands to draw into.

And IF your opponent is playing land destruction AND enchantment hate, slide them out second game, not big deal.

157975: Endless Horizons.author: endersblade
157975: Endless Horizons.text_parsed:
Tranquility
Tranquil Domain
Tempest of Light
Cleansing Meditation
Spring Cleaning
Back to Nature
Austere Command
Cleanfall
Primeval Light
Patrician's Scorn

And about ten others, but I think you get the point. If you are stupid enough to remove ALL of your lands with this card, you deserve the loss. There is just way too much enchantment hate that doesn't care about shroud, or just about anything else you'd try to use to protect it. I know an EDH player that consistantly removes at least half of his lands with this card, and it ends up getting blown up before his next turn. Every single time. Then he's land screwed for the whole game. I can't imagine watching someone actually do something like that, or worse, in a 60 card deck...

If you really, really want to run this card, add in token-multiplier cards like Doubling Season, Parallel Evolution, and Rhys the Redeemed.
>Since Rhys is in there, may as well Elvish Promenade for some more doubling shenanigans.
>At which point you add cards like Shields of Velis Vel and Mirror Entity to make all your Goats Elves and all your Elves Goats.
>Since you're already playing a ridiculous deck, you can play with Wort, the Raidmother and conspire your Parallel Evolutions, Elvish Promenades, and (just because you can) Shields of V.V.
>It probably won't be until, like, turn 30, but when you feel you've had enough fun you can sack all those Goat Elf Goblins to Springjack Pasture, cast your Banefire and conspire it to kill two other players (because there's no way you're going to pull this off outside of multiplayer).
>Of course, you probably could have won a long time ago by using Mirror Entity to pump your myriad of tokens, but then there would be no point in having Springjack Pasture. And if you're not playing Springjack Pasture, then you probably would never have built the deck in the first place. So if you do try to win with Mirror Entity, your deck will implode from the paradox of its existence.

157976: Springjack Pasture.author: Asmodi0000
157976: Springjack Pasture.text_parsed:
If your deck has room for colorless mana producing land, this card is not a bad addition. It's nice when you're manaflooded and you're just trying to stay alive, but it's too mana intensive (essential 5 mana for a 0/1) to really shake up a game.

It's a nice card to sit on in multiplayer games, since no one really pays attention to the guy that only has three or four 0/1 tokens on the field, and they're great for chump blocking the stray creature that does come your way.

And, when it's time for the alpha strike, you sack a few goats for extra mana to play your big spells, or drop a Glory of Warfare or Overrun and just kill them with goats.

A solid card, but if you're looking for a 0/1 token producing land, Kher Keep is a little better. I run both cards, and it's bit of a shame that I usually end up tapping Springjack for mana to help create Kobolds.

157977: Glen Elendra Archmage.author: Kenji18
157977: Glen Elendra Archmage.text_parsed:
If you get it to stick with Juniper Order Ranger, you will be able to counter as many noncreature spells as you have blue mana. Each sacrifice will also pump the Ranger, too. So, you get a big Ranger with a good way to protect him. I'm sure stock went up with the Ranger when persist came out, so I don't imagine that this is an original idea.

Another good idea would be to use her with Sigil Captain. When she comes back into play, she will be a 1/1, so Sigil Captain's ability will trigger, making her a 3/3 with no -1/-1 counters. Same idea as the Ranger, but the combo is standard legal.

157977: Glen Elendra Archmage.author: Paolino
157977: Glen Elendra Archmage.text_parsed:
This card can mean INFINITE NONCREATURE COUNTER FOR EACH if comboed with Melira, Shirei or Sage of Fables... The combo with Sigil Captain also works, because the creature's power and toughness are checked when it enters the battlefield, and so counters that enters with the creature and continuous effects (such as Elesh Norn's power and toughness alterations) are counted.
There are different "layers" for power and toughness determination, and are (in order):
1) characteristic-defining abilities (for example Nightmare: "this creature's power and toughness are each equal to the number of swamps you control");
2) effects that set power and toughness to certain values (for example Diminish, "target creature becomes 1/1 until end of turn");
3) effects that modify power and toughness (for example Immolation: "enchanted creature gets +2/-2");
4) counters which affect power and toughness;
5) effects that switch power and toughness (for example Dwarven Thaumaturgist).
For example, if I control three swamps and a Nightmare with a +1/+1 counter enchanted with Immolation and targeted by Diminis and Dwarver Thaumaturgist's activated ability:
- it's 3/3 for the three swamps,
- then Diminish makes it 1/1,
- then Immolation makes it 3/-1,
- then he +1/+1 counter makes it 4/0,
- then Dwarven Thaumaturgist makes it 0/4, and it DOESN'T GO TO THE GRAVEYARD because the 0-or-less toughness is checked on the total of all the effects; at the end of the turn Diminish and Dwarven Thaumaturgist's ability will end and it is:
- 3/3 for the swamps
- 5/1 for Immolation
- 6/2 for the +1/+1 counter.

157978: Evershrike.author: mdakw576
157978: Evershrike.text_parsed:
I'm surprised this never saw serious tournament play, at least when lorwyn was in standard. It's got a decent recurring ability that makes it hard to kill. Yeah, hardcasting it kinda sucks, but like others said, there are ways to get it into your graveyard without hardcasting it (like discarding it via lightning axe or something), and bringing it back afterwards shouldn't be a problem. The other thing is, the problem with auras is that you can get 2-for-1'd, but since players can't respond between the time evershrike returns from the graveyard and when you put an aura on it, it can easily be saved.

I must be missing something that made this card not good enough for tournaments.

157978: Evershrike.author: Zetan
157978: Evershrike.text_parsed: This card is so amazing. On turn 1 you can discard it with something like Cabal Therapy or even Blackmail ("Hey, check out these two Swamps I'm revealing! Oh, and I'm discarding an Evershrike.") and by turn 2 you can Dark Ritual it back out with any number of awesome one-cost enchantments, most of which people have already named here. You don't even have to be playing the color of the enchantment, he grabs it for colorless converted mana cost! Rancor is a great option even if you aren't playing green, and Edge of the Divinity is another obvious choice. Either one makes this guy a turn-2 flyer with 6-7 power... not too shabby.

157980: Hag Hedge-Mage.author: distinctactuality
157980: Hag Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
@X3n05had3: Yes it would.
When HHM enters the battlefield, if you control a forest, a swamp, and an overgrown tomb, his first ability would say: "hey look, two swamps, I tink I'll activate", then his second ability would activate and say "hey look, two forests, I think I'll activate as well". Both abilites are independant of one another. Of course that means that if you cast him with 2 Overgrown tombs and a Birds of Paradise, both would activate as well.

158103: Crumbling Ashes.author: CaptainGeardark
158103: Crumbling Ashes.text_parsed:
Holy crap, this card has a rating below 3.5? That's absolutely ridiculous... I mean, it's very specific to some decks, but in infect or wither (where it was admittedly meant for) this thing is absolutely ridiculous. I mean, Soul Snuffers is the most obvious of the uses for this, plus Carnifex Demon for repeated creature destruction. May not be a quick board sweeper, but if you get it out on turn two, it could keep the board pretty empty on your opponents side for a while.

Or, at least long enough to get your Kulrath Knight out.

158104: Balefire Liege.author: Asmodi0000
158104: Balefire Liege.text_parsed:
The king of my deck. At least, he and his two brothers share that title. Having 2 out at a time is great, and 3 just makes things silly, but I also play Soul Foundry, which means I've played games where 4 and even a game where 5 of them were out on the field at the same time. Sadly, their ability isn't triggered when a token of one comes into play. However, a single lightning helix went ahead and dealt 18 damage and healed me 18, followed by a stampede of 5 10/12's, which brought my opponent down from 50 life to nothing in a heartbeat.

Great with Crown of Flames, and also is awesome with Skyknight Legionnaires. There's something undeniably satisfying of sending out a skyknight and dealing 7 damage and healing 3. It's even more awesome when you slap on a Scourge of the Nobilis on the Skyknight and end up dealing 12 damage and healing 12 in the same turn.

One more interesting thing- Scourge of the Nobilis is cool to place on a balefire, because the lifelink makes it so that every time you cast a r/w spell, you deal 3 and heal 6, since he's the one dealing the damage. It also turns him into a pretty nasty 4/6 with pump, but it's almost always better to never attack with him.

He's also great for use in a token deck, since he boosts both springjack pasture sheep and kher keep kobolds, as well as making rise of the hobgoblins a really nasty threat. Combined with Glory of Warfare and Nobilis of War, supposedly harmless creatures become absolute monsters.

158106: Figure of Destiny.author: flippythekist
158106: Figure of Destiny.text_parsed:
I think that the idea that this card is overrated is just silly. he justifies it by saying that 90% of the time he can deal with it right away.....well why is it that u are dealing with it "right away"?....oh its cause its a good card. Cards only demand answers if they are threats and this guy is a big threat. he plays sever roles throught the game that cannot be ingored, a 2/2 for echo for R isn't bad, and an attackign 4/4 on turn 3 can put on the beats, and then he can Finish it withan 8/8 Flying!.
This card is early, mid, and late game all very efficiently.

The idea that just cause u can kill something doesn't make it good is just plain silly, and if u follow that logic u will find yourself playing with only Regenerators and Dark steel Ingots....but oh wait, those can both be removed from the game!!! WHAT IS A PLAYER TO DOO??????

the answer: Play with good, efficient cards. Like say...figure of destiny.

5 out of 5

Though it doesn't give you as much card advantage I much prefer playing a 1/1 for 1 the first turn then more 1/1s or 2/2s the following turns there are some strong things that you ca pull to keep your board full and adding some abilities doesn't hurt. especially with the double strike that seems to be prolific with RW creatures

158106: Figure of Destiny.author: Bandswithother
158106: Figure of Destiny.text_parsed:
I too don't understand these complaints. This guy is a potential threat whenever he hits the table, and demands removal. A weak player will waste a kill spell on him early when a strong player will wait till he poses a real threat. All the while you're casting other spells and generating other threats that the opponent will have to answer to when it comes to endgame. Since this guy can be leveled with otherwise wasted mana (not saying you should tap yourself out every turn) his threat grows with the game. My point is if he isn't removed he will become a game ender; if he is removed then he's just a R/W Duress.

On the subject of removal, yes everything does in fact die to removal. If anyone thinks that a card is terrible because of its vulnerability to doomblades, bolts, paths, and other spells then they must think this whole game is terrible, which begs the question as to why they're here commenting in the first place.

158106: Figure of Destiny.author: Asmodi0000
158106: Figure of Destiny.text_parsed:
It is a little disheartening to see a card you play rather often (since he's not very difficult to cast) eat the dirt before it gets a chance to really show its true power, but you get used to it after a while. A 2/2 swinging on turn 2 isn't too bad, and it works nicely with Boros Garrison in regards to that early game tempo. A 4/4 that can swing on turn 3 is also excellent, and people should be happy enough to see that before it gets killed.

And, you mustn't forget, that in the games where he manages to survive all the way to become an 8/8 first strike flyer, it's more of a "win-more" card, since your opponent can't be in a great position if he let that happen. Though, while "win-more" cards aren't strategically great, they certainly have a great deal of style.

It's interesting to note that if you just happen to have a spare 11 red/white mana sitting around, you could drop him and level him up all the way to his final form in the same turn, though I will admit that something has gone terribly, terribly wrong if a red/white deck finds itself sitting on 11 mana.

Overall, I prefer him to the true level-up creatures because of one vital factor. You can activate his ability at instant speed, which is often an important consideration when you make him a 4/4 to outpace a lightning bolt.

158293: Antler Skulkin.author: majinara
158293: Antler Skulkin.text_parsed:
The only reason I can see to play this is in a reaper king deck, where it on the one hand serves as ammunition, and on the other, even more important, can give the reaper king persist (which he will need since any player will try to kill him asap).
For those purposes the thing ain't bad. Or, alternatively, if you can paint your scarecrows white, this thing is nice as well with reaper king, since the scarecrows that persist back to play will trigger the reaper king a second time.

158599: Woodlurker Mimic.text_parsed: This is one of my favourite cards. 158599: Woodlurker Mimic.author: MisterAction
158599: Woodlurker Mimic.text_parsed:
This card is CRAZY. I stumbled across it one day, then did a search here for every GB card and randomly threw a bunch of them together, only to wind up with a ridiculous level of power.

Turn 1- Play a land!!!
Turn 2- This guy.
Turn 3- Consume Strength, most likely killing their only blocker and swinging for 6.
Turn 4- Cankerous Thirst, most likely killing their only blocker and swinging for 7.
Every subsequent turn- Creakwood Liege or Maelstrom Pulse.

I'm none too eager to do the math on what it would cost to purchase all those cards and build a hard copy of this deck, but... man, GB has some scary stuff under its umbrella.

158899: Noggle Bridgebreaker.author: majinara
158899: Noggle Bridgebreaker.text_parsed:
The ability can be turned into your advantage actually. Examples?

1) if you played no land this turn and have none on hand, play this guy, return a land, replay the land, and it basically costed one mana less.
2) Landfall. Bounce a land, replay it and trigger landfall stuff again.
3) Lands with charges that you used up, or with come-into-play abilities.
4) For cards that care about your handcount, since you can play this guy and keep the same handsize.
5) For stuff like seismic assault to get new ammunition.

It's not great but playable. 4/3 for four mana with a slight advantage in the right deck is nice. 3.5/5

White can prevent it all (I'd even sideboard a Circle of Protection: Red or two if I knew I was facing this, especially if there's Painter's Servant shenanigans afoot) and blue can just counter it outright, and there aren't many answers for either in red.

159066: Noggle Hedge-Mage.author: Atmos
159066: Noggle Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
Eventide really worked blue over (due to Faerie decks being rather overpowered at the time it was printed), and the blue enemy colors were largely weak or disappointing.

However, the hedge mages were pretty close to being incredibly cool creatures, on par with the Guildmage cycle from Ravnica, and this one is one of my favorite.

Both effects are pretty sweet for what they are. My sole, minor complaint is the red trigger ability only hitting players, I would rather it hit creatures as well. 3 mana for a shock and double twiddle on a creature, but with a rather nasty requirement (for non-green anyway)..I'd say it's fair.

Barring Steam Vents, there is no way to get both effects without four lands in Extended (valid as of this comment), so I seriously doubt it would be unbalanced in any real way.

Still, I like the semi-surreal nature of the "noggles" and this card in particular was one of the few bright spots that the Red+Blue combination got in Eventide, but it's a really cool cycle all the same.

159066: Noggle Hedge-Mage.author: OMFGrhombus
159066: Noggle Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
@ garbagegatherer
A noggle is a creature of British folklore. It is actually a horse, not a donkey, and wanders around the countryside wearing a saddle. As soon as someone gets on the saddle, it dashes to the nearest body of water where it jumps in, turns to steam, and generally inconveniences its victim. So, if it were to have a different creature type, it would be horse rather than donkey.

159066: Noggle Hedge-Mage.author: Trygon_Predator
159066: Noggle Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
This is actually quite a strong effect, especially in formats like Commander where manabases are huge. Steam Vents and/or Volcanic Island are necessities if you want our noggle friend out as soon as possible, or instead play it late-game and flicker it.
Also of note: its converted mana cost is , which means it can be played at instant speed for free with Aluren. Combined with an engine like Cloudstone Curio, it can be bounced back and forth off the battlefield until you've pinged your opponents to death. Ghitu Slinger saw play in Aluren decks for the same reason.
All in all, a quite reasonable package considering the limitations, and easier to combo with than Duergar Hedge-Mage (the most utilitarian of the Hedge-Mages).

159067: Selkie Hedge-Mage.author: Atmos
159067: Selkie Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
The sole weakness of this hedge-mage is the lack of the true "Man-O-War" effect; why the "tapped" condition? Then again, Wizards was likely worried about effectively reprinting Man-O-War during a time where blue decks (or rather, Faeries) had taken over Standard and Blue needed to be brought down a peg.
I'm fairly certain that's why it was designed this way.

However, I find that to be a inadequate reason to limit the bounce ability on this creature, considering that the format at the time revolved around Comes Into/Leaves Play abilities, and a three drop that resets your opponent's Spellstutter Sprite/Kitchen Finks sorcery speed would not have broken anything.

Sadly, even after rotating out of Standard, the poor Selkie Hedge Mage has nowhere to go, and it's a shame since it was so close to being just right.

The green ability really doesn't share anything with blue, but that's fine. Green has had lifegain since the dawn of Magic and it fits here.

The creature types were part of the archetypes chosen for Eventide, but even so, Merfolk and Wizards have no shortage of buffs and effects, though one would be hard pressed to splash green into Merfolk as printed.

Overall though, it's a solid, if a bit underwhelming, part of a good cycle.

159067: Selkie Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
This girl is more attractive than she really should be.

Anyway, the tapped clause isn't as big of a deal as one would expect. Most of the time the creature you'll want to be bouncing will be tapping to attack you or use a good ability anyway. I give it a 3.5/5.

159067: Selkie Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
I get that people aren't very happy about the tapped condition, but you can get a lot of bang for your buck here. If she just had man-o'-war's ability she would be absurd. Keep in mind she could choose to bounce herself, which is probably why they added the restriction.

A decent body, a splash of life and delay a threat. (Or abuse another comes into play effect) If she was also a repeatable Healing Leaves then she would be too much. She won't place in tournament decks, but she is an excellent play for anyone else running simic colors. Also just fun.

As for her appearance, she should be attractive. Selkies are very specifically attractive, its one of their defining features in every story about them. (the other is that they turn into seals.)

159068: Duergar Hedge-Mage.author: mdakw576
159068: Duergar Hedge-Mage.text_parsed:
wait, people think this card sucks?

if played correctly in edh, it's one of the easiest 3-for-1s i've seen. It's 3 cmc so you can recur it with sun titan, its 2 power so you can reveilark it (or just use karmic guide), it is even generous enough to have a may clause so you can throw it out whenever. 2 power isn't very big, but it's still a chump blocker to stop certain swords from hitting you (namely feast and famine), something you can sac to a grave pact, etc. much better than using disenchant or the like.

even in constructed this saw play when it was in standard, and is even a viable sideboard card in modern, mostly for boros aggro decks where they just want as many creatures as possible, and the fact that this isn't instant speed doesn't matter when they get a 2/2 with it.

159068: Duergar Hedge-Mage.author: DoragonShinzui
159068: Duergar Hedge-Mage.text_parsed: The whole Hedge-Mage cycle was a lot of fun. Flexible, and you were almost guaranteed one of two handy effects on an appropriately sized creature.
